I sometimes don't have my drum on me, either... ...  ...   ...     ...okay: This is the tastiest soup there has ever been, or ever will be, until the end of time. No joke.Zeus is a small cafe that's sort of in-between the first floor and the basement of Goldwin Smith Hall on the Cornell campus. Their focus is on fresh and healthy lunch-time options, with a special focus on vegetarian and vegan options (all of their soups are vegetarian, one of the two daily soups is vegan). Soups are fragrant, uplifting, colorful, savory, euphoric, and impossible to ever forget. Try Groundnut or East African Stew, and be transported to a far-away land where ginger, peppers, peanuts, and spice toy with basmati and the luckiest yams in the world. Try Thai Carrot with its silky orange puree and coconut-lime-chili medley. Or, sip cilantro-strewn gazpacho to tame a 90-degree summer's day. All soups are made fresh that morning by a couple of the most under-appreciated culinary geniuses (C and N) the heavens ever gave us. If you can get past the soups (which you can't), go for a B.L. Tease (cooked tofu mixed with smoked gouda and a bit of mayo; bacony for the vege kids!) or the seitan-and-hummus, with it's garlicy garbanzos. Heaven should taste like Temple of Zeus soups. If it doesn't, it should shape up now so it's ready by the time I get there.", 5, 2]}

The last few times I've been there for dinner, it's been iffy. I was there on July 20, 2016, and it was a severe disappointment.  It was a Wednesday night and very hot and humid outside. There were very few people there, and it was prime time for dinner, a little past 6:00 PM when we arrived. Of the many dishes they had, few had been refreshed or replenished in hours. Many were lukewarm at best. It was like they saved it from lunch. I was hungry when I left because there were so few things to really eat. We stayed for over an hour, until past 7:00, and it only got better marginally. When they did upgrade a dish or two, it was a small quantity. The dumplings, which were cold and hard, had about seven new ones added to it. They never added more to the Mei Fun. The Tofu dish looked old crusty and unappetizing. I heard people behind me complaining about the food as well. Now, I realize that sparse attendance on that night might have been responsible (they didn't want to make a lot of new food and have it go to waste, I suppose), but the owners should have been ashamed of themselves. It wasn't like it was 3:00 in the afternoon or 9:00 at night...this was prime time for a dinner buffet. To top it off, I witnessed something very disgusting, which I should have reported to the Health Department, but didn't. I had to use the Mens Room shortly before I left the restaurant. While there, one of the kitchen staff, a man in his 50s or 60s, with a kitchen cap on his head, was using the urinal. When he finished, he turned the cold water on in the sink, while walking quickly past the sink, let a few drops of water hit a couple of fingers on one hand, and took off back to the kitchen. There was no soap used, and the amount of time he \"washed\" his one hand was less than five seconds. He didn't even dry his hands. That was it for me. I told my wife, who was eating with me, I won't be returning for a very long time. It's really a shame, this was once a great place to go. You could count on the food being good (admittedly, the food seems to be better at lunchtime, when there are a lot of people eating on their lunch break from work) at dinner. There is a new buffet in town that opened last year, Spring Buffet, down the road closer to Downtown Ithaca. Frankly, I don't find the food at the new buffet to be better than the older buffet(when it's been good there), but it is always plentiful and the place is clean. (I would like to point out that at this time, the restaurant was not busy, there was a table of two, and a group of around 10 asides from the three of us at the restaurant). We ordered sashimi, various rolls, and for dessert, ice cream. The sashimi served to us were dry, and clearly not fresh. The rolls were likewise not appetizing, but acceptable, given the fact that there was only one sushi chef making the food for the entire restaurant (only one person during dinner on a Friday night?). The ice cream we had for desert, had the texture and taste of ice cream that had clearly been sitting in the bottom of the freezer for a few months (and while the menu claims to have green tea and strawberry, and vanilla flavors, after we ordered, the server promptly told us that the only flavor available was vanilla).However, what is most ridiculous was the event that pushed me over to signing up and writing my first Yelp review. After the three of us paid and were walking out the door, our server had the audacity to come up to us and claim we \"forgot\" the tip. I don't know what industry standards are these days, but I tip when I receive good service, not because of the fact that someone is operating a business in the states.By the time we left, it was past 10:00, we were not satisfied, and I will definitely not be returning to this restaurant.", 1, 9], "GwEaQBZfTxtj-ItaJLEOng": ["Yelp", "Capital State Kitchen Incorporated", "10/27/2011", "Decent sushi at a good price. Fortunately the Yelp app picked up Simply Red located a few miles out of town. The Bistro is the house restaurant for a beautifully located old hotel (La Tourelle - great valley views). The dining room has a vaguely mid-European feel, enhanced by the stunning stained glass ceiling. Promisingly, the lunch menu was also quite simple in the Euro style (soups, salads, some interesting sandwiches and a \"themed\" set lunch - in this case Chimmichurri!). Why more restaurants don't do their Sunday brunch on Saturday as well, we'll never know. but this is beside the point.Whenever I do manage to get a Sunday off, brunch is the first item of business. Simply Red recently opened up shop in Danby as the restaurant for La Tourelle - the inn and spa.  This is a second location for them, in addition to their restaurant at Sheldrake - and since I have long been a fan of Simply Red (mostly because of their fried chicken!), and because La Tourelle is close to home for me, I had been anxious to give their brunch a try.The service was great and I loved the big, cushy, and super comfortable chairs. I was able to snuggle in and let myself hide from the real world a little longer that morning. I like the atmosphere there, despite it's being a hotel restaurant. The brunch came with pastries, which were totally unecessary because the brunch portions were truly enormous. but hey, everyone likes pastries so I won't complain. I ordered the crab and shrimp eggs benedict which was absolutely to die for. I think this plate had to have been 4000+ calories - it was just swimming in the richest, most delicious hollaindaise sauce I had ever had. My husband ordered the giant burrito, which was indeed made for a giant - and was spicy, messy, and yummy.The brunch was also very reasonably priced - we each had coffee, juice and at least three times as much food as a person probably should eat for breakfast, and well honestly I don't remember what the bill came to, but we were both impressed that it wasn't a more expensive brunch. So now I am plotting to take off more Sundays, so that I can eat the Simply Red brunch again. In the meantime, you should go and eat brunch there for me - it makes me so sad when restaurants stop doing their wonderful brunches (I'll never forget you Maxies brunch! Or you, Just a Taste brunch!). The first thing to arrive was a truly heavenly yogurt parfait featuring loads of fresh fruit, chocolate chips, nuts and a yummy cinnamon granola. That was followed by a basket of warm pastries, served with a sweet butter. Divine. And so filling, I could have walked away happy then and there. But then I would have missed out on the biggest treat of all: oatmeal crusted french toast with fresh strawberries, drizzled with a brown sugar cream. Wow, wow and wow! My partner was equally happy with his classic breakfast of eggs, bacon, taters and toast. It felt like a real splurge, but at $11.95 per person for everything, including drinks, it's actually the bargain of the century. And afterwards, we were happy to walk off some of that grub by exploring the woodland trails that wrap around the gorgeous grounds. That's because it's a quiet bar that's best for small gatherings or even reading/working alone (note the lending library). For folks traveling through or visiting the area, check it out.", 5, 1], "rEfmR4CHuFK4cDW3Hy2hmA": ["Yelp", "The Watershed", "3/11/2017", "Simply put, this is an outstanding addition to the Ithaca Commons bar scene. It's a light, easy place to sit and have a few drinks at, whether you enjoy a unique cocktail or a locally-brewed beer from a microbrewery. The atmosphere is what's sold me on this place. It's quiet but lively; the decor is subtle yet vibrant. Nothing is overdone. It feels like a speakeasy in the 20's. The tables are real wood and have an authentic feel. Everything seems new, yet comfortable. The bartenders were friendly and accommodating as far as our lack of intense beer knowledge went when asking for a recommendation. There's a wonderful \"lending library\" lining a few of the walls (some great reads too, for my fellow literature nerds). It adds to the aesthetic, though I didn't have the courage to take a book home with me. If you're looking to expand your beer palate, they carry a Bacchus Brewing Fly South WPA that I enjoyed immensely. I'm not sure how long it'll be available, but it's a grapefruit-infused ale that sips full and deep. We tried an Irish Stout from Bandwagon that we didn't like as much, but it was worth trying. The one drawback is that the place isn't massive. We had some trouble finding a table, and had to share one with two other couples. It's not bad, as it forced us to meet others, but... not always ideal. This was a Thursday night around 9:00, so a relatively busy time, and I would imagine this isn't always the case. They give you nice wine bottles full of water with your drinks, a nice quirk. We'll be coming back, sooner rather than later. Two weeks ago when I sat down for dinner with a group of friends for my birthday I asked if they could do a pineapple jalape\u00f1o pizza. The waitress said they didn't have jalape\u00f1os but recommended we try banana peppers instead. Oh my god, that topping combination was heaven. A few months before that I ordered a pizza with red peppers that were not very good, so I would say that this was a huge improvement.Perhaps my favorite item on the menu is their unusual chicken wings. The chicken wings are really crispy but not battered. In addition, the buffalo sauce is unique. It has a hint of some sort of holiday spice in it (maybe nutmeg or cinnamon) that really makes them unusual. Everyone at the table loved the wings, and wished we ordered more of them. They also have BBQ sauce wings and those were also quite tasty. One person at my birthday dinner ordered boneless wings but I didn't get a chance to try them, because the group scarfed them down too quickly.Northeast Pizza shares a space with Scale House Brew Pub, and hence you can order beer directly from the brewpub on tap. I don't usually drink beer so my taste in beer is not very refined, but I enjoyed all the home brewed flavors I have tried here. They brew several different kinds but only 3 - 4 of them are actually available at any given time.Everyday of the week they have a special of the day that rotates, and then repeats each week. Some days its a discounted extra large pizza. Other days its an order of wings with a medium one topping pizza combo deal. Either way the specials are the cheapest way to go.lastly, the atmosphere is quite fun. On the brewpub side the scale house has a few TVs that shows various sporting events and also have live music on select nights of the week. Often this music is quite folky. On the other side of the pizza parlor side they have a bowling game machine. The pizza parlor slash brewpub combo makes the place feel kind of like a PG version of a townie bar. I generally prefer to sit on the brewpub side because the appointments are nicer and it got us further from the door so cold air was not blowing on us. You can order things from both places at the tables from either side of the establishment.", 4, 6]}

Instead, I'm giving 4 stars for being the only pizza place in town that makes a decent NY-style pie. The crust is thin, but not crackery. The sauce is simple and garlicky, not too sweet or overloaded with dried oregano. And the cheese is that glorious, gooey mass that smothers the entire thing, with that familiar fluorescent orange greasy glisten. Basically, it's an oily gutbomb of a pizza. But, as a displaced, homesick New Yorker, this is the type of pizza I want when I get a pizza craving. If you want a thick-crusted pizza with tons of toppings, or an artisan pie with locally-sourced ingredients, or a papa john's knockoff, this is NOT the place for you (not that there's anything wrong with any of those!) But if you're like me, and miss the slightly shady by-the-slice joints that exist on every corner in the NY tri-state area, this is your best bet. Behind the bar, a handsome bearded and chatty bartender took us into his care. We got four cocktails that featured local ingredients. We laid out our certificates and asked the bartender, if she would please describe the different types of Rioja wines to us. Enough said!", 5, 0], "UTmhn64mRyFFzmF8YP6zRg": ["Yelp", "Scale House Brew Pub", "12/26/2011", "I love micro brew pubs and whenever I travel I try to drink local. So, when visiting my in-laws for Christmas I found my way into the Scale House to grab some home brewed beers before dinner. Seeing that they usually have only three types of beer I ordered their Pilsner and my brother-in-law got their dark Bock. I would have ordered their red ale but they were sold out. My Pilsner tasted like water. Sure. There was a hint of hoppiness and evidence that fermentation did actually occur, but for the most part it was just slightly carbonated yellow water with particles of little somethings floating on the bottom of my glass. Not good. I tasted my brother-in-law's Bock and it was better with some darker tones and flavor but it still wasn't anything great. In fact even though we had 40 minutes to kill before we had to head back home we just nursed our sad beers and had no longing to order a second round. Add in the odd assortment of art school student painted murals of fruit bowls, wolves, and waterfalls I had to look at, and the tacky and dirty holiday table clothed tables where I had to rest my arms, and I really have no reason to come back here. It's too bad. Their website is top notch and their food menu looks promising but this is one local mirco brew pub I will not be coming back to the next time I'm visiting family.", 2, 2], "MCP61NDPB-9eDidm3idvWg": ["Yelp", "Scale House Brew Pub", "11/16/2010", "Good beer, hand crafted and brewed right at this location. Now when I'm in Ithaca, I always stop at the Ithaca Beer Company on Elmira and sample all the beers fresh from the tap. But when I'm up for a meal with my brews the Scale House is the place in Ithaca. I belly up to the bar and order a pale ale and take a few sips and savor the flavors that Bud and Coors just can't ever produce. Then I get up and cross the imaginary line in the floor and wonder over to Northeast pizza and order a slice or two of their bar pie with black olives and xtra cheese. A few minutes later my slices are delivered by one of the Cornell or Ithaca College students who work here. The slices are piping hot and not at all like that thin pizza you get in the city, these slices are thick and chewy with an acidity/sweet/garlic-y sauce with mellow but flavorful melted cheese that tastes more like a blend of whole milk mozzarella, provolone, and perhaps a bit of munster or brick cheese for added richness. The black olives add just the perfect amount of salt and brine to round out these flavorful slices of pure pizza perfection. The pale ale is a perfect beer to accompany the grease from the cheese. When in Ithaca, eat where the brainy Cornell students eat and imbibe and that's at the Scale House Brewery located in a tiny shopping center behind a rundown hotel off Tripphammer road just past the Tripphammer Mall. Enjoy!", 3, 4]}

This is what happened to us with the Crossroads Bar & Grille in Lansing.What I like most about the Crossroads is that it's completely unassuming. It looks like a run of the mill bar that serves food. One side is the bar and the other side is the restaurant separated by a half wall. Sure they serve up your standard bar food fare but the difference is that it's amazingly good and relatively cheap! Tonight, my husband and I shared the special: a full rack of carolina style ribs which came with coleslaw, super tasty sauteed broccoli (who knew?!) and bacon & cheese grits \"fries\". The ribs were truly unbelievable....the best in the area in my opinion. They weren't slathered in BBQ sauce but covered with a delicious rub and cooked perfectly so that the spices formed an almost caramelized crust. We were totally stuffed for only $20.99. I was excited to find out they had Ommegang Abbey Ale on draft.....delicious with the ribs and oh so classy! After we paid the bill, our server came by with a complimentary brownie which we ate even though we were still full. A perfect end to a perfect meal.....the Crossroads Bar & Grille does not disappoint!", 4, 8]}

I wouls recommend this place.", 5, 2], "3-bfFgxjUGDF-ptY4aHtKg": ["Yelp", "Souvlaki House", "10/29/2008", "Souvlaki House makes the best pizza in Ithaca. Now, you may think that I am contradicting myself, that I said the same thing about Sammy's. What I said about Sammy's is that they make the best New York style cheese pizza in Ithaca. However, the hands-down most delicious pizza made anywhere in this town comes from Souvlaki house. Their house special pizza is something spectacular. First off, the crust, always hand stretched from freshly made dough. This is the perfect foundation, as it always comes out perfectly crispy on the bottom, yet extremely moist and chewy on the inside. Even with a mountain of the greasiest toppings piled above, this crust always maintains its integrity. You could eat this pizza off your lap and have not a stain to speak for it. The sauce is decidedly mild, a plus in my book, as the sauce is not what I consider to be the centerpiece of the pizza. The cheese, likewise, is good, fresh mozzerella which serves as an excellent binder to tie everything together. What makes their pizza, however, are the toppings. The house special is topped with fresh sausage, pepperoni, bacon, green peppers, mushrooms and onions, all in extreme quantities. When you get this pizza you can see the care that goes into it, as all the toppings are perfectly distributed radially across all the slices. Each piece in its own is a work of art. Last time I went here, my friend and I ordered one of these; when the waitress brought it out, she put it down, stepped back and said \"wow, you guys have a great pizza here.\" That pretty much sums it up better than I ever could. Their other Greek selections are quite good as well, though the quality of the pizza makes limits my motivation to expand my horizons very much. I've had their eponymous souvlaki, and it is indeed name-worthy. The Greek salads, dolmas, spanakopita, baklava, and everything else that you would expect in a Greek restaurant are definitely up to par. Everything is made fresh in the open kitchen, right before your eyes. The owner is the nicest guy in the world, does a lot of the cooking and prep work himself, and is always standing there with a smile when you go to check out. If you want the best fork-and-knife pizza or Greek food in Ithaca, this is the place to go.", 5, 3], "DI_9mIpf9P1T4efRpuu6Mw": ["Yelp", "Souvlaki House", "8/20/2008", "I used to loooooove their Greek piza with feta cheese and olives. However, avoid the Salvadorian food; it simply isn't worth it. My rating is based only on the Italian- American dishes.The specifics: Italian- American food- I have ordered a few different pizza pies from this place, but my go to is the Fresh Mozzarella Pie, and it is quite good. All the pies that I have had seem to have quality ingredients. The corn-meal dusted crust is crispy and just the right bulk and it stands up to the most hefty toppings. The red sauce is thick and chunky and not too tart and not too sweet, and that is how I like it. The garlic knots are crispy and well flavored, though a little bit greasy and unnecessarily dusted with corn meal. The calzones are enormous for their price and the quality of the ingredients is, like the pizza, very good. I am a fan of the Popeye and vegetarian calzones; the crusts are crispy, and the filling is generous.Frankly I don't get my fellow Downstaters (Long Islanders, NYC folk, etc) pizza elitism or being thrown off by Latin music playing there; you either make a good pizza or you don't and this place belongs in the former group. The Salvadorian food- I could write essays on this. I ordered a chile relleno plato tipico. It wasn't a poblano or a hatch chili. It was a green bell pepper. There was no cheese, and there was no meat. The veggies were those you'd usually find in a cheap frozen mix and they were mixed with mashed potatoes. The whole dish was rather flavorless. It was about 4 degrees outside, 4 or 5 inches of snow on the ground and continuing to snow. A friend of mine and I take a break from a project and walk down for soup. I'm not lying when I say their udon and soba got me through some of the worst winter days up here, and I've enjoyed their food for years. We order and sit down to wait for the food to come. The woman manning the counter (I think she might be one of the owners) comes over and offers us hot tea and seaweed snacks, both of which we didn't ask for. The food came out and it was as delicious as ever (especially after the snow and cold outside). As we get up to leave, counter woman stops us, offers us dessert, and thanks us for coming by in spite of the snow. That's just the sort of place Cafe Pacific is. I had a great experience overall.", 5, 2], "ahDuUmFKSQuKnNWRH3EcEA": ["Yelp", "Cafe Pacific", "7/13/2014", "I'm not sure whether some of these other reviewers have experienced authentic Japanese comfort food, but this is by far the best Japanese restaurant in a college town otherwise starved of decent Japanese food. Hoshino-san, the owner, is a friendly and great guy. He knew me by name, and would even often come to my group's concerts. If I came back late from campus, I could rely on this place being open until midnight - sometimes they would even keep the kitchen open for me. My club also often did team dinners here, and they were very accommodating, even offering us free desserts on occasion.My favorite item here by far is the yakinikudon (similar to gyuudon but with sukiyaki-style meat), especially when you ask for it extra spicy. The curry is more on the watery side, so I'm not a huge fan (I like it nice and thick), but has a great flavor. The tonkatsu and unagidon are other great items to try. The zaru soba is also standout here - refreshing for a hot day if you stay in Ithaca over summer. I found the ramen options to be so-so; great if you're craving ramen since you have no other option in Collegetown, but definitely not comparable to the better places in New York, let alone Japan.Desserts and drinks here are also good; their molten chocolate cake and coffee shake were staples of my diet (to my detriment) while I was in college. I wouldn't recommend the bubble tea; go down the street to the Old Teahouse for that.Again, if you're looking for the typical American Japanese sushi-teriyaki experience, don't come here; you have Plum Tree or Miyake for that. If you want authentic home-style Japanese comfort foods, this is the place to go. All in all, my favorite restaurant in Ctown, and I always make sure to stop by every time I visit!", 5, 6], "LIgkIToe5QXOdeME3khStQ": ["Yelp", "Cafe Pacific", "5/10/2014", "The sukiyaki and nabeyaki udon are pretty good, and so are the molten chocolate and lava chocolate cakes.The best part about Cafe Pacific is the people who work there! It was only a matter of time before I tried to articulate what my taste buds do every time I visit. First and foremost, let me clairfy these 5 stars - Chipotle gets 5 stars for FAST MEXICAN food in Ithaca. It's local. I've eaten at the competitors, I've done my \"thing\", and Chipotle always leaves me happiest. So, \"you\": a health conscious, busy, passionate person. And hungry. As mentioned in a previous review, I have unorthodox ways of eating. I eat my burger bunless. If you know me, you'll realize when I like something, I like it all the time. ALL the time. Carrots, for instance, are a daily staple. Salsa and fresh food tickle my tummy. They make my GI tract happy, my tastebuds sing, and I feel like I\"ve made a great life choice. Naturally, I would want alot of it, exclusively. Chipotle delivers, judgement free. OK: Chipotle from front door entry to exit and how it's a 5 star experience (if you're me). Walk in: the place is cool, crisp, clean, open, bright. This is imagery of a 'cleansed and ready' appetite. Competitors are darker, cluttered and cramped which is not the 'feng shui' for good digestion. I follow the stream of people to a well-stocked line of industrious workers and good looking food. The menu is well organized and straight forward: no surprises - you're getting standard American-style Mexican cuisine, just pick your base (taco, burrito, salad, etc) and your meat (or non-meat) which just HAPPENS to be naturally fed (an unexpected win playing on my 'health conscious side' -- I cared about the environment without even trying!). Let's get to the food - that's what you're reading this for anyway. New paragraph. My choice has little variety: I eat the salad with no beans, no rice, no sour cream, no cheese, no guacomole. Extra cooked veggies and small heaps of beautiful, beautiful salsa. So why, if I have such a restricted preference, does Chipotle get 5 stars? Because they absolutely kick-'butt' in the department of 'extra salsa, extra veggies'. Further, the salsa are fresh, diverse, and well seasoned and spiced. I've had the pleasure of sampling their chips as well - a win win win for all you chip-fans! They have a lovely citrus/salty zing to them which makes the salsa pop. I fear a sour-cream laden dish would smother these fiesty yet delicate flavors right out of their perfection. But wait - as you progress through the highly efficient line and pay for your dish - it isn't over. Chipotle tabasco sauce - it's life-changing. The smoked flavor plays into the salsa (especially the corn salsa) giving it that 'base' which a dairy product would destroy. Think of the smoked tobasco as the tannins in a great cab sauv. That's waiting for you, with lemon wedges, after you pay and prepare to indulge in the best fast-mexican-food experience out there (in Ithaca). Be forewarned - your tastebuds will be dancing from the spice (but not torched so as not to taste anything). Conveniently, Yogurtland is a neighbour in this epi-center of good fast food and a terrific place to finish off that \"food crawl\" you won't soon forget. With that, Chipotle gets an EXTREMELY subjective 5 stars. Thank you Chipotle for the extra salsa. This place is authentic New York style pizza. That means two things, 1) they do thin, hand-tossed crusts with basic tomato sauce and mozzerella cheese, and 2) they make a bunch of pizzas in the morning and leave them out all day for people to buy slices from.I would not eat anything I ordered from inside the restaurant unless I was absolutely starving. I got a chicken parm sub there once and it was okay; it didn't kill me but it wasn't Louie's Lunch quality, that's for sure. The slices are just not worth getting. If I want reheated pizza, I'll do it myself tomorrow morning, thank you. This is no fault of Sammy's, the same holds for Mama T's, Sinbad's, and CTP. Of these, Sammy's does actually have the best reheated slices: Mama T's is neutral, and Sinbad's and CTP taste like dirt and cardboard, respectively.  So where Sammy's shines is in making whole pies. And I mean, come on, you have to give them a chance, that's where a pizza place gets to do its work. Now, I have not had a great variety of their pizzas. I will say that their meat lovers' pizza had an indescribably vast quantity of ground-up animals on it, was completely black on the bottom, and leaked so much grease that I had to put a towel under the box for fear it would ruin my table. It was not my favorite thing in the world but it did the trick and I didn't want to eat for a few days thereafter. But the reason why Sammy's is still getting my business is that they make THE BEST CHEESE PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD. Their plain pie has a simple elegance the likes of which are rarely seen. The dough is perfect and gives rise (no pun intended) to an excellent crust with a nice chewy little twang to it. You can really feel the gluten in the flour giving it that stretch that so many puffy, doughy crusts lack. The sauce is subdued, with no harshly sweet or rusty overtones, and kept to a minimum in quantity, allowing the cheese to interface with the crust and adhere nicely. And to top it all off is just the right amount of cheese, with that nice saltiness that sits on top of a layer of true fresh mozzerella when it is baked. Delicious. I have had so many of these pies, and every one is as good as the last. Get the 19\" and eat if yourself.  Basically then, the three star review is just an average. The walk in stuff gets one star, the specialty pizzas get three, but the cheese pizza, the best in Ithaca, that's five stars.", 3, 11], "4TSdbAbGvtX0QNGpnB7fIQ": ["Yelp", "Sammy\u2019s Pizzeria", "10/19/2008", "Probably the best NY style pizza in Ithaca. This kind of mistake happens quite often with several of the ingredients and it just shows that management doesn't care about quality control. (2) Inconsistent portions. Food is great, and service is great. I am a New Yorker who has been to most of the best Szechuan restaurants in NYC, and have found this place the best! The taste of each single dishes were fabulous. I think many dissatisfied customers of De Tasty Hot Pot may have had the wrong expecations of Chinese restaurants and Szechuan cuisine. Szechuanese cuisine is often spicy, salty, fried, and oily. That's just the style of the cuisine. As for the service at a Chinese restaurant, De Tasty Hot Pot is clearly not the Statler - judging service in stereotypical Chinese restaurants by Western standards will only lead to dissatisfaction on behalf of both parties. But as David Chang wrote so eloquently: \"Here's the deal: things do not work the same way in a Chinese restaurant as a Western one. The waittress does not come to the table and tell you her name is Amanda and the chef has this and that special and blah blah blah. Instead, she lurks around wherever she likes until you snap your fingers or wave your hands to let her know it's game time.\"-Lucky Peach Magazine Issue 5 (2012)I'm sorry if the waiters aren't coming around to ask for your order - the Western style of service is simply not something they're culturally versed in. Please give the food a try (see top items at the list below)------------This place is pretty solid. Don't get the hotpot, order from the menu. The dishes are really authentic, decent portions. Reminds me of Mary's in Cambridge.", 5, 5], "DSEtYoNWH71MyhBbJN_1pQ": ["Yelp", "De Tasty Hot Pot", "1/22/2015", "We went to the restaurant tonight and loved it.  Our experience was unlike any of the negative reviews here. The waiter spoke fluent English, walked us through the hot pot menu options. Food arrived promptly and was beautiful. We had a chicken broth and a spicy broth for our single pots, and a seafood combo and a meat (pork) combo.  We also added one plate of cabbage dumplings. The seafood combo included whole head-on shrimp, mussels, fish, surimi (\"crab\" sticks), squid along with a plate of different vegetables, tofu and vermicelli. The pork combo had a plate of micro sliced pork and the same vegetable plate. The broths were complex and delicious. There was a table with additional sauces if we wanted to add more flavor.  During the meal we talked about how much fun we were having.  As non-Asians we were definitely a minority in the restaurant. We were offered forks, which we declined, as part of what we felt was excellent service.  The total bill, including tax and the 20% tip we added was $52 for the two of us.  While slightly higher than many of the Asian restaurants in Ithaca, we felt it was offset by the taste and fun. In addition, the hot pot meal takes a bit longer and the pricing may reflect the less frequent turnover. As for the spelling errors in the menu, their English abilities far surpass my Chinese ones (which are mainly limited to eating delicious food).  We will be back again soon.", 4, 12], "Q2ESs54r82REpduBM94E0w": ["Yelp", "De Tasty Hot Pot", "12/6/2014", "The people who gave this place one star have no idea what they're talking about. It's really authentic Chinese food and arguably one of the best Chinese restaurants I've been to.It's a bit pricey if you get non-noodle dishes and the portions aren't the biggest, but the taste is definitely worth the price. If you want to get a cheap meal, their noodle soup dishes give you a TON of noodles for around $9. If you like Chinese food, you're in for a treat if you go here. If you want to go for dinner between Thursday and Sunday, make a reservation otherwise you won't get a table. If it was not a hot pot restaurant, it would deserve NO stars for the reasons listed below:1. AMBIANCE | The space is dingy and there is very little lighting.2. STAFF | They are extremely understaffed and barely speak any English. I understand that English can be a difficult language to pick up, but if you're opening a restaurant in AMERICA, you or at least one person on your staff should be able to speak English.3. MENU | Unless you can read Chinese or want to spend some nice quality time deciphering the poorly written menu, good luck placing your orders!4. PRICE | Extremely over priced! I ordered the pork combo. The only thing that could have been \"expensive\" was the literal pot (which they wash and reuse) and possibly the pork. Besides that, the combo included: half a plate of cabbage ($0.50), 2 SLICES of mushroom ($0.02), 2 1/2-inch thick slices of corn ($0.50), 3 SMALL PIECES of fried tofu ($0.50), 2 PIECES of wood ear ($0.10), and a small bundle of vermicelli noodles ($0.50). All of that equates to just under $3.00; add on the pork and maybe it would be $8.00, max! So, when I got my check that read $17.77, something seemed off. Turns out, they charge $4.50 for the pot & broth--and it's NOT included with the combo price of $11.95. So, what if I just wanted the combo? No, I have to get the broth too or I can't COOK my food--literally. Bottom line: OVER PRICED!5. CUSTOMER SERVICE | Their customer service is HORRENDOUS. Besides lacking the ability to communicate in English, I was the victim of racial profiling. I was the only Asian at my table and after 1 waiter could not communicate to us adequately in English, another came over and began speaking to me in Chinese--assuming that because I have ASIAN features, I spoke CHINESE (what about Korean? Japanese?). Turns out, I am Chinese and I can speak basic colloquial Chinese--but, if I couldn't, they wouldn't have even been able to take our orders. Regardless, we ate our dinner and then the check came: $17.77. Aside from what was mentioned above, we were explicitly told our meal would only cost $11.95--because we were told the combo included the broth (which would make sense since you can't eat it without the broth). I am not a confrontational person and I usually handle these situations by paying the bill, writing a Yelp review, and never returning. However, my friends are a lot more vocal than I am and wanted to speak to the manager because we were told false information. While they spoke to both the waiter and the manager, each of the staff members would not respond directly to my friends, instead, they spoke to me--involving me in a conversation that I did not ask to be a part of. Not only was this extremely rude to my friends, but also extremely rude to me--abusing my ability to speak their language so they could get out of talking to unsatisfied customers directly. Then, they had the nerve to tell me that previously, they had told me how the pricing worked--COMPLETELY FALSE. All conversation about pricing was done in English. All ordering of food was done in Chinese (since the menu was predominately in Chinese). This situation was so shocking to me and I will NEVER go back again. Pretty understaffed so expect long wait. Conversational knowledge of Chinese highly recommended. Also hot mainland waiters!", 2, 5], "yvQXhR7ChfGJA9nU9pzJWg": ["Yelp", "De Tasty Hot Pot", "11/12/2014", "The quality of a Chinese restaurant, I hypothesize is highly correlated with the number of English words misspelled on the menu. You'll have a hard time holding in your laughter at some of De Tasty's amusing word choices and spelling mistakes. I couldn't wait to try their \"secrete recipes\", \"doodle soups\" and \"shredded potato shredded potato.\" They specialize in hot pot and Szechuan cuisine. If you have never had hot pot before, it is a simmering pot of flavored broth at the center of the table. You order ingredients off a menu and place them into the broth to cook and eat. As the meal goes on, the broth gets more and more flavorful, taking on the flavors of the meats and vegetables you cooked. SZECHUAN MENU and LUNCH SPECIALS: The Sichuan Lunch Specials are the best lunch specials in collegetown. My favorite dish is the twiced cooked pork. I also really enjoyed their Ma Po Tofu, shredded potato, and their Fish fillet & tofu w/ roasted chilies. The Kung Pao Chicken is also tasty, but this dish is better at \"Spicy Asian\" on Rt. 13 (side note - De Tasty gives you a much larger serving of rice with your meal than Spicy Asian does - a huge plus in my book). The lunch portion serving sizes are quite large and cheap for $7 - $9. The specials come with a cup of soup that is usually clear broth or egg-drop (nothing special, but a nice touch considering it's free). The dinner portions are even larger than the lunch portions and a good value. On the appetizer portion of the menu, the dan dan noodles are absolutely fantastic. Over all, if you are frugal, the regular Sichuan menu offers more food for your money than the hot pot menu.HOT POT:The hot pot is good, but in my opinion the regular menu offers a much better value. The spicy broth was great, with a very distinct clove and chili pepper flavor. You first order broth for $5 per person (or $9.50 per large pot, whichever works out cheaper). Then you can either order individual items to add to the broth or purchase a combo to add a variety of items (noodles, several veggies, and your choice of meat). My suggestion is to only order one combo to share with all the people in your party and then add other items that match your individual tastes. Buying as many combos as people in your party will be expensive. They have many tasty items to choose from: dumplings, shell fish, different cuts of meat, fish balls, 25 different types of vegetables and yes they even have \"fish tofu\". For those who have never tried \"fish tofu\", it's very tasty, but just a hint, it isn't vegetarian and tastes nothing like tofu. For those who don't like sharing a communal soup, this place has small personal pots. This way, if your dining companion is really into intestine, but you'd prefer not to have intestine flavor getting all up in your shrimp, well that doesn't have to happen. The spice/sauce bar near the counter can help flavor your soup and is especially important if you ordered the chicken or herbal stock as those are less flavorful than the spicy broth. Hot pot usually works out to be $15 - $20 per person without tax and tip.CONS: Probably the biggest downside is the language barrier and sometimes inattentive service. If you don't speak Chinese, you might have difficulty communicating with them. In addition the hot pot menu is somewhat confusing, which can make the language barrier more frustrating than at other authentic Chinese restaurants. Some of the other reviews say this place is pricey given that you cook your own meal. While the hot pot can be expensive, that statement is a bit absurd; it would be like claiming you cook your own microwavable TV dinner. All of the labor is in the prep; just because you place items into the pot doesn't mean you are doing most of the work. The \"cooking\" is part of the fun, otherwise, why are you at a hot pot restaurant. I've eaten hot pot here 3 times and paid about $13 - 20 per person before tax and tip depending on what we ordered. Note all 3 broths (chicken, spicy, and herbal) used to have a meat stock base, so strict vegetarians were out of luck as far as hot pot goes back in 2014 [[ EDIT: a waiter now told me that the \"herbal\" broth recipe has been changed to be vegetarian as of 4/20/15 ]] . Several of the entrees on the \"vegetables\" section of the menu are vegetarian. If this place were in a big city I'd probably only give it 4 stars, but I am so excited that a decent Chinese restaurant has finally come to collegetown. They definitely get an extra star given the lackluster options within walking distance from Cornell.", 5, 24], "Lqqnq4i4Osz_pl5-4OaOaw": ["Yelp", "De Tasty Hot Pot", "11/12/2014", "I'm giving this 5 stars because in spite of some small issues, the food is delicious and Collegetown needs all the decent restaurants it can get. We decided to go Korean and came here.On a Saturday afternoon, there were a few tables occupied. The staff was not at all very welcoming (see Jason S' comments). They have a decent sized menu that included BBQ, tofu casseroles, noodle and rice dishes, and some Japanese fare. They even advertize soju and Korean beer on their walls. I wanted the OB, but they said they didn't get a shipment in, how odd! So this is what we ordered: Seafood pancake, cold Bim Bim Bop, chang chang myeon, tofu casserole, and bbq beef. The seafood pancake was delicious. It was very crispy and had pieces of squid and shrimp. The sweetness of the dipping sauce helped balance the flavors of the pancake. The Bim Bim Bop was good too. It was a big bowl of julienned vegetables, daikon, carrots, lettuce, mountain greens, etc., topped with a fried egg. Rice was served on the side. Mixing the vegetables with the rice and the spicy Korean fermented soybean sauce made the dish have a complex texture and flavor. The chang chang myeon (I forgot how to spell it) is somewhat like the Chinese version, but with more of the darker/blacker sauce and little meat. It was only okay.The tofu soup was somewhat disappointing. It did not have the typical flavor of most tofu casseroles I've had in the City or around Fort Lee. The soup base was thin and lacked the complexity of fermented soy bean paste. It tasted salty like to much bonito. And they forgot to give us a raw egg! The BBQ beef tasted like it should, but I think we just ordered too much food to even enjoy it when it was hot. For a place like this in a college town, I would give it 3.5 stars. We ordered the daily special of coddle, fish and chips, scotch egg, what we thought was going to be duck confit but turned out to be quail?, and a massive pig trotter's dish. The coddle was unexpectedly thickened, more of a stew similar to chicken and dumplings than a traditional coddle. Still very tasty with lots of meat bits and good veggies, bit on the salty side. The fried fish was very fresh although quite thickly battered. We had fun eating the chips with the four different sauces that came with it. The scotch egg was well-made and came with lots of delicious accompaniments like soda bread, pickles, and Irish cheddar. The quail was cooked rare with some bacon wrapped around it - tender with good flavor, but a lot of work to deal with little bones. Would have preferred the skin to have been crisped. Will go back on my next trip to Ithaca.", 4, 1], "FYYlTsGKlM4-9JiqpR-XzQ": ["Yelp", "Kilpatrick\u2019s Publick House", "5/7/2010", "I've waited to try this place a few times in order to write a well-rounded review, and my experiences have always been good. FOOD: good, hearty meals that come in sizable portions. A quick run through of what I've tried: the Shepherd's pie was heavy, filling, and tasty. It was kind of blunt in term of flavors, but I think that's kind of what I like about the soul-food-iness of shepherd's pie in general. The Grilled Chicken and Brie is pretty delicious and filling. I like the Brie, instead of say Havarti or something, because it did not overpower the red-wine-marinated chicken (which is moist and flavorful) while still adding that creamy richness that I love about brie. Surprisingly, the lightly toasted asiago loaf adds a lot to the whole shebang. The Corned Beef and Cabbage was decent; the corned beef was all I could ask for and more when it comes to corned beef, but the cabbage didn't add much. I know, cabbage is usually just a light side to offset the heavy meat, but I think cabbage can still bring a fresh palate cleanser to the meal. In this case, not really. The dish was, however, still quite good. The Kilpatrick's Grilled Chicken Breast is also quite good. It was the first dish I ever got, so I don't remember it will, but it was one of the reasons I came back, if that says anything. Note --- there are some good vegetarian options, not just side salads! I brought my vegetarian friend who usually hates \"bar food\" but she really liked this place (vegetable sandwich, butternut squash ravioli, etc). DRINKS: Good selection of beers, nice selection of whiskeys, and okay selection for other drinks (not that the other drinks should really matter if you're headed to a pub, right?). I didn't really notice their wine selection, so I can't comment on that. I like the taster of four different kinds of beer if you're in the mood to try new stuff (the four glasses come on a, what else, wooden shamrock). They also have some good, cheap specials ($3 Red Ale) if you want quantity over quality. SERVICE: Not too bad. I think the last server we had was kind of new. She was very attentive. When we asked for another few minutes to look at the menu, she literally came back three or four times, with almost exactly one minute in between each return. We just wanted to take our time and we felt rushed and bad for sending her away so much. She also couldn't remember the specials, didn't know too much about the menu, and couldn't remember the beers on tap or bottled beer. The time before, the waitress was really good and friendly. She knew all the beers on tap (there were a lot) and knew the specials like the back of her hand. AMBIANCE: I really like it. Private booths in back, very homey and private, snug when you need it to be, while also being surprisingly roomy and good for small groups (about 6). Loved it. In the front, there was a much more pub-like feel. I really like the overall feeling, with the mid-darker wood, warm lighting, and gridded windows. I kind of forgot I was in Ithaca...oh the joy. RANDOM ISSUE: I want them to make up a base drinks menu. I'm sure there are some beers they ALWAYS have, so why not just let us look at those and then fill us in on the specials or whatever? Sometimes I have trouble ordering when I'm bombarded by fifteen or something different available beers. Overall: give this place a shot if you want a fulfilling meal, a decent selection of drinks, and a place removed from Collegetown/the main part of the Commons.", 4, 6], "wWAEdvkx8Za9Vn896xNn_g": ["Yelp", "Kilpatrick\u2019s Publick House", "2/17/2010", "Food is decent Irish pub fare, but the service here is consistently bad. Ahi Tuna Salad: Fresh greens, the yuzu soy dressing isn't bad. Decent portion - be aware that the Ahi is 3 thin slices which are well seared on the edges but nicely raw in the center. A totally decent salad, but nothing special. 8/102. Roast duck puff pastry samosa:Comes with a tamarind-mango sauce and what I believe was a chutney with whole mustard seeds. The problem is that puff pastry is rich and butter, combined with the sauces which were very sweet, and the rich and heavy filling - this was just dense and unbalanced. Furthermore, the duck in the filling felt like it had been braised for a lot time to the point of toughness. 7/103. Alaskan Crabmeat & Vietnamese Sausage Wontons:Disappointing. The filling lacked the sweetness of crab but also didn't really have any significant savoriness or any flavors that reminded me of vietnamese flavors. The soup was decent. There were 5 or 6 very small wontons in this portion. I just felt like the main attraction here, the filling of the dumplings, did not deliver. 6/104. Pan-seared Tandoori Quail:The quail was tough. I tried cutting it with my knife and it didn't work. I resorted to picking it up by hand and biting it directly. Also, the spice blend on the outside of the quail was passable but they had completely forgotten to salt the quail. The quail also lacked any browning or maillard flavors, it just felt like the spice blend had been stuck on. The spices didn't taste particularly well toasted or bloomed prior to being rubbed on. The raita on the other hand, was thicker than usual and saltier than usual. Solid concept, perhaps, but poor execution. 5/105. Passion Fruit Frozen Souffle:First off, this is a big portion. The passion fruit flavor isn't bad, but they may have oversweetened the base as the brightness isn't as punchy as a great passionfruit dessert is. This is fairly hard, but not that dense. Frozen souffle is a fairly apt description, I suppose. I would guess that the recipe is for a semifreddo. The raspberry sauce (we had no caviar) was completely forgettable - tasted like the raspberry gel on a supermarket cake. I have had better but I would definitely return just for the pork buns!I went here for dinner after months of anticipation based on all the good reviews and the familiarity with the owner's other restaurants. I have to say that the food was a bit hit and miss. I wanted to see how a diverse number of dishes was prepared, so my friend and I had a number of dishes from the left side of the menu. Our line up consisted of tom kha gai, raw sampler, crispy duck roll, BBQ pork buns, foie gras, and baby back ribs. Lets get the bad news out of the way. The tom kha was way too sour and rather thin in terms of texture and amounts of ingredients. The foie was pretty disappointing, thus ruining my perfect streak of awesome foie dishes. The foie was cold with no sear on the outside to add a level of texture and flavor that I am used to. It was also pretty awkward to navigate the dish as the puff pastry on the bottom was very tough and hard to cut through without demolishing the delicate foie. I don't think the baby back ribs were even baby backs. They tasted like spare ribs, and much like the foie, they were inexcusably cold. They were tender but not enough to effortlessly fall off the bone like I am used to. The flavors were satisfyingly and distinctively umami, though. Now the good part! The pork bun was a pleasure to eat and the number one reason why I can't wait to go back for another round. The bun was perfectly steamy and soft. The pork was extremely well prepared and the crispiness contrasted with the softness of the bun. The daikon provided a third texture to the dish that was all tied together with the sauce. This dish was fantastic and definitely the best item on the menu that we had. The raw sampler was very well prepared as well. All three fish were wonderfully fresh and paired with sauces that synergized each bite. I really appreciated the translucent ruby color of the ahi tuna. The only aspect of this dish that I wish was different was the presentation. It was hard to share this dish as it was served in tasting spoons. Otherwise, it was perfect. The crispy duck rolls had lots of great flavors with the freshness of the herbs playing a large part in the flavor profile. The roll itself was thick enough to give the dish substance and was fried perfectly crispy. For all dishes, the presentation was simple and clean, which was a great example of how less is more.The interior of Mia is very well done. There are plenty of colors that are stimulating and simply just work. It is a tasteful mix of different designs elements and colors that makes your eyes wander. The one aspect that I thought was really interesting were the tables. They edges were tapered to give an impression that they were wafer thin and delicate. Luna is unfortunately not a great addition to the scene. I've eaten there several times throughout the years and unfortunately it continues to underwhelm.Their interpretation of bao buns is a big chunk of meat covered in sauce and a big pickle. A satisfying bao bun should be bursting with shredded greens and carrots and very succulent meat that doesn't need a thick layer of sauce to tie everything together. The pho-rito is another good example of what goes wrong. Pho ingredients stuffed in a burrito can be promising, but the secret to delicious pho is the broth which enriches the meat, bean sprouts, and noodles. Without the broth (or some clever substitute) all these ingredients are bland, which is exactly what the pho-rito is. The flour tortilla also seems to be just slightly warmed from a package. With a bit of effort-- seasoned ingredients, handmade tortillas-- the pho-rito could be amazing, but they take the minimum effort route.All in all, there's a huge lack of effort that I think Luna gets away with because there's no competition. There are greek diners, which are large, sparkling and have massive menus. Then there are greasy spoons, which are essentially the opposite but strangely charming because of it. I have always been partial to a good greasy spoon, and the Lincoln Street Diner is the best I've ever been to. As an undergraduate at Cornell, the Lincoln Street Diner was my refuge when I needed to escape academia and be around normal people for a little while. I became a regular at the Lincoln Street Diner not only because the diner is run by a great group of people and because it is cheap but also because the food is damn good. Expect standard diner fare and you will be pleasantly surprised. They do staples superbly (Friday Fish Fry, Meatloaf, etc.) but the owner Chris can also get creative with the lunch specials and offer some very interesting, tasty dishes (be sure to keep an eye out for his stuffed burgers). For lunch, my recommendation is to go with whatever is on special and be sure to get a soup. You can get a soup in lieu of a side which can make for a cheaper and healthier meal.If you go on a Saturday for breakfast, expect a bit of a wait as it will be packed. In sum, there will always be a soft spot in my heart for the Lincoln Street Diner. It is the Cheers of diners. (There is even a mailman that is a regular: #CliffClavin.) Home fries are crispy, flavorful, not greasy. Coffee is dark roast and good, refilled frequently. The option of fresh squeezed o.j. is always nice and, overall, the menu, including specials are a neatly contained pantheon of good quality, locally sourced foods that you want to eat for breakfast, lunch or brunch. They don't try to do too much in their tiny space, and what they do they do well. Portions are just right, plates are attractively presented. In sum, there is nothing that smacks of Denny's of the place, including the quaint location. Negative: The service. Blas\u00e9, inattentive, and strange for so few tables easily in view -- there are mirrors everywhere. Maybe they rest on the food and the central location to bring back customers. I think one of my favorite moments there was a server very nonchalantly headed towards a blind patron as he approached, taking his arm and leading him right to a table (it seemed pretentious upon first site for me, since the cafe is essentially in a hallway between all of the first floor shops and is not always a person's destination when walking through - but it became clear that this was the man's intention). She knew what he wanted but asked politely if he wanted something different that day. It was clear that he is there often, and that the staff know and treat him well.The menu has the appearance of being healthy - I couldn't vouch for whether or not this is actually the case, but I tend to want to go to the Dewitt Cafe when I don't want fried or otherwise greasy food (ok I always want fried and greasy food - I should say that I go there when my *husband* wants to eat a healthier meal). Portions are on the smaller side in comparison to most restaurants - but of course in other words, this means that they bring you about as much as you actually want to eat, instead of a gluttunous portion that ends up with half of it going to waste. I enjoy the food here - it is simple and it is well done. The regular menu items as well as the many specials are always good. In fact, I don't believe that I have ever had a bad meal there. And I love the desserts - I think this is where they excel the most. The variety is key - a dessert menu that always changes is a way to guarantee that I will appreciate a restaurant! (don't even get me started on some of the restaurants in town that change their small dessert menus only once every 5+ years!).The service is interesting. I know, not an adjective that a manager would want to be hear as the only descriptor. It is beyond laid back - it is almost aloof. Everything ends up happening fast enough, but you just always wait a little longer than you want to, or seems necessary. In some ways I appreciate that it's not a hustle and bustle crazy scene (seeing servers run marathons around you can be rather distracting in its own way), but especially when the cafe is packed (on weekends!), you just start to wonder why there isn't a little more jump in their step. It's not a huge issue for me, but again, I just find it interesting.Prices are perfect, if not generous. Be aware though that they do not take credit cards! Please read what others have the say:1. Hidden inside downtown Ithaca's small DeWitt Mall, Cafe DeWitt serves up delicious breakfast, lunch, and dessert fare with a European flare. Lined with fish tanks, mirrors, and odd lite-brite installations, the cafe looks a bit like a small, modern cafeteria. While the cafe isn't strictly vegetarian, the veggie options on their menu stand out in terms of quality. They serve up lots of egg dishes, pastries, and pannini sandwiches. Plus their desserts are amazing. Not the best place for vegans, but good if you eat dairy and eggs.2. Located in the same downtown Ithaca shopping center as the Moosewood Restaurant, this Euro style cafe excels at brunch fare. The place is somewhat easy to miss - the space is kind of open-air towards the back of the DeWitt Mall. The mirrors and fish tanks make it look like there's more to the space than just the eating area.The food at Cafe DeWitt is excellent. Their egg dishes are great and the veggie pannini I had was delicious. I think their pastries are made fresh every morning. The dessert menu is also mouth-watering. I had a yummy lemon pound cake, but the day I was there they also offered lavender creme brulee, some special meringue cakes, a couple of chocolate items, and some locally made ice cream.Cafe DeWitt only does breakfast and lunch, so you have to get there before they close in early afternoon. Another observation was the drink/dessert menus weren't wiped down and literally had dried soy sauce spots on them. As I'm looking through the Japanese menu, I was searching for the a la carte section (Nigiri). I was told it was on the take-out menu so here comes a 3rd menu if I wanted Nigiri. There are a couple errors on the take-out menu such as \"Salmon\" being spelled \"Sakmon.\" Also, it states on the take-out menu that Happy Hour is 3:00pm - 5:30pm but on the plastic stand that sits on the table it states 3:30pm - 6:00pm. I also want to point out there is literally a picture of a hibachi table on the menu. There isn't a single actual hibachi table inside the restaurant. A complimentary volcano roll was given to us, which was 3 pieces and mainly rice. Suspicions rose and I asked what the volcano roll was filled with and I was told \"white fish.\" A very unnoticeable amount of \"white fish\" was found inside the roll and it only tasted of deep fried rice. Though complimentary, I could have done without. So I wanted to start off with the Shumai and Gyoza. The Shumai came out barely lukewarm, and came with an overly strong sauce. I'm not shy of strong sauces, but this will hit your sinuses and make you lightheaded. The Gyoza was actually quite tasty. The filling was tender, and the was nicely done. I then ordered Nigiri which consisted of Scallop, Super-White Tuna, Yellow-Tail, Salmon, Tuna, Mackerel, Sweet Shrimp and Ikura (Salmon Roe). I think the Yellow-Tail, Super-White Tuna, and Scallop were the highlights. The Tuna was just alright. The Salmon was odd to me. It looked fresh in colour, but tasted off. The Mackerel and Ikura had to be the biggest disappointment. The colour of the Mackerel was off, and very dry. The Ikura is the worst I've had. Old Ikura is what I had. To the point where the shell or skin of each roe would literally stick to the inside of your teeth. As for the Sweet Shrimp, didn't taste quite fresh. Onto the rolls. I'm very saddened to give this restaurant such a low score because I see potential. The presentation is phenomenal and I truly feel the chef is creative and skillful making sushi. Unfortunately, the best way I can describe this restaurant is it's a beautiful car with a bad engine. While I may not be Asian, I want real Asian food when I go out to eat, not any Americanized Asian food. So we were both incredibly disappointed in the food, again, and also in the service again as well. And once again, we observed different treatment for us as compared to others in the restaurant. So, due to this treatment and the decline of the freshness of fish and the not authentic Sichuan, we shall not be re-visiting Mitsuba and shall get our Sushi fix elsewhere. And for Sichuan, we will head to the place down on 13, or we will make our own. Like I said before, when we go out to eat, we expect the cuisine to be representative of the country it comes from, not some Americanized version, and we also expect the service to be the same across the board for all customers.", 1, 4], "-XO0_JyYVNesY5kHGt_PRA": ["Yelp", " Mitsuba", "12/10/2014", "I have been on a sushi kick for weeks now, so when the craving hit I decided to head to the place with the highest number of great reviews! Mitsuba is a relatively new place; none of my coworkers had heard of it and even during the dinner hours they were almost empty. Obviously this was just fine with me as I didn't have to wait to sit down and my food was out fairly quickly.The place itself is nice. It's very spacious and the set up is generally attractive, though nothing special. This is your standard dining hall look, so might not be right for a romantic night out.The service is good, albeit a little weird. None of the servers really engaged with us from the moment we came in, until we left. They asked only the most perfunctory questions and avoided eye contact. I'm chalking it up to a cultural difference? Other than that, however, everything was very nicely done. We got hot towels for our hands (especially nice when it's freezing and snowy outside!) Soon after sitting down, we were surprised to get a free volcano roll. Unfortunately, my friend and I are both vegetarian so we had to send it back, but the gesture is awesome! Finally, as I mentioned, the food was out fairly quickly.Note that you will not get tea with your meal as is so frequently the case in Japanese restaurants. For whatever reason, Mitsuba only offers water. You can, of course, order tea, but it's always a nice little perk to get it for free. Not a big deal, just something to keep in mind.The vegetarian rolls all looked very appetizing, so I had a hard time deciding and ended up getting four rolls: the avocado peanut, avocado cucumber, sweet potato, and the house vegetable maki. The first three were excellent and I would highly recommend them. The house vegetable maki was a little weird, but it could just be personal taste. Since this was the most expensive roll, I was disappointed that it was not my favorite, but it was no big deal. I think something about the melange of vegetables just didn't work for me. The price is completely on par with other sushi restaurants and way cheaper than Wegman's, so nothing to complain about there.One thing that I noticed and really liked was Mistuba's reciprocity with yelp. If a customer writes a review, they get a free appetizer, checking in usually results in some sort of freebie (in my case it was a miso soup); in short, using yelp will get you tons of good deals here! The wings are really large for being on special. I find other places use wing specials to get rid of the runts, but Uncle Joe's seems to hoard them until Mondays. It is only $5.50 a dozen and they are cooked perfectly every time. I usually get the hot Ralph's wings. They are pretty hot but not remorsefully or painfully hot so that sauce is a winner in my book. I have had the garlic parmesan and sweet and spicy wings too, but I like mine really hot.The burger special on Tuesdays is, by far, one of the best deals in town for price and quality. All burgers are cooked to order (medium rare thank you)!!! Most places give you well done hockey pucks but these 8ozers are amazing. I have had all the burgers here and they are all delicious. I find myself getting the Uncle Joe's burger more often than not. I love the crisp, fresh lettuce, tomato, and onion that come with most of the burgers. The fries are ALWAYS extra crunchy and crisp. It seems like they don't sit around too long in the back and are served fresh.I have had the pizza special on Thursday but it is pretty dismal compared to the wing and burger specials. The dough tastes premade and almost biscuity rather than doughy. The sauce and cheese leave something to be desired.The walls are covered with TVs and other sports memorabilia. I love watching Yankees' games here and can't wait for the NFL games on Sundays. I sure hope they have the Red Zone channel!The biggest contention I have with Uncle Joe's is their beer selection and prices, especially during Happy Hour. I'm kind of a beer snob and I don't like lite beer. There are very few choices outside of the mega-brewers. The beers are $2.75 at happy hour. I just don't like paying that much for lite beer at a small local joint like Uncle Joe's. Waaaaa I'm crying I know, but good food deserves good beer.The service here by the waitresses is almost always slow. I have sat for 5 minutes without menus on a few occasions. Don't expect speedy service on drinks either. A few of the servers were rather robotic in their service without much personality. Service while sitting at the bar is much faster.I really like Uncle Joe's, mostly for the food. The sandwiches are as big as a mini van! Plenty for dinner tonight and lunch tomorrow. Where else can you get two meals for $7 in Ithaca?The place is modest, open kitchen and counter seating for those who choose to dine in. Not much more is needed for this little gem of a sandwich shop. We stopped in last night for the first time and were impressed with the clever menu. You can get any of their delicious sandwiches on either flat bread or a sub roll. In additon, there are several vegetarian options. I had a tough time deciding on which sandwich to have there were so many wonderful choices. I had the Caribean Fire which was spicy and flavorful. The scotch bonnet mustard sauce had plenty of flavor which was balanced with heat. My companion had the chicken bacon ranch. The ranch dressing has a bit of a dill flavor which was great, not your typical from the bottle ranch dressing. The bacon on the sandwich was cooked perfectly. It's also pretty unreasonable to not expect a wait in a place that makes everything fresh, especially if there's a line. As a person who has actually eaten there and understands the concept of having to wait for food made better than that at a greasy fast food joint, I have to say that this is the best sub shop in town. The rolls for the subs are fresh and yeasty, the homemade apple/cabbage coleslaw is divine and the owners are generous and attentive. They asked my friend and me what kind of music we'd like to listen to while we ate and one of them even shared his homemade sriracha sauce with us. The atmosphere is small but cozy with a polished granite eating space and a wall of local low-brow pop art for sale that's delightful to look at and affordable; I took one home with me for 10 bucks. The menu is wonderfully eclectic, with subs topped with everything from Argentinian sauces to elements of French-Vietnamese baguette sandwiches that you can only typically find in bigger cities. The price also can't be beat. Why get a microwaved meatball sub at a chain when you can get a bahn mi or a savory treat topped with a wine reduction for 7 bucks? I hope this place sticks around for a long time and gets due attention!", 5, 0], "F0QwIXqfU3mopphE965z5A": ["Yelp", "Gorgers Subs", "9/24/2012", "A coworker and I ordered from Gorgers for lunch last week. Using that lens, Applebee's needs to be revived as a serious contender. It's true the entrees are unholy--packed with sodium and cheese, and spliced together into veritable Frankendishes of American fare in huge proportions, but some of the straightforward items in the 2 for 20$ deal, which also gets you an appetizer, are not bad. Case in point: the sirloin steak. Drinks here are sugar-loaded, and sometimes I wonder if some wonk could compute Applebee's contribution to US diabetes prevalence. The ambiance fits kitch to a tee, but the Ithaca location has some local flair to differentiate it. The service is consistently decent and can sometimes even be good. The real thing to do, as other reviewers have hinted at, is to go see a late-night movie, then head to Applebee's for half-off wings. There's something romantic and reassuring about walking hand-in-hand late at night through a desolate parking lot in a non-descript suburban wasteland to Applebee's after taking in the latest Hollywood soma...I mean film. You realize in those moments that you need someone real, and you appreciate your partner's quirks more than ever. They become even more human and their company is especially comforting against an American cultural landscape that can seem positively soul-crushing at other times. In short, it is completely possible to go to Applebee's, enjoy your time there, and walk out without having turned into a zombie. They were busy, but the waiting staff found us a table and helped to provide a very pleasant dining experience. I think Miyake is a fine restaurant based on three things - its setting, service, and quality of food.Miyake is in a prime location in College Town. It is close to Cornell's central campus, making it a very popular restaurant for students. You can walk over, or even park your car by the side of Eddy Street. The inside of the restaurant is clean, warm, and cozy. The traditional Japanese d\u00e9cor enhances the dining experience, and the enormous sushi bar creates a very welcoming atmosphere. I went with a big party, and the waiting staff managed to seat us all around a pretty big table. Because of its two big dining rooms, the restaurant's layout can be suitable for both big and small parties. The heat from my Tempura Udon was making me feel a little stuffy so I felt like I could have used a little more space at the table where we were seated. But besides the space at our table, the setting and ambience of the restaurant is wonderful.The service at Miyake was excellent. For a party of our size, the waiting staff did an awesome job of managing our orders, requests, and dishes. Their punctuality and consistency was especially noticeable when they brought all twenty-two of our dishes out in a very timely fashion. The waiting staff constantly kept an eye on our table, and were available for us whenever we needed assistance.I ordered the Tempura Udon - Udon noodle with shrimp and vegetable tempura in broth - for $15.95. I thought the dish was delicious. The broth was very aromatic and the noodle was cooked perfectly. I also loved the presentation of all the dishes. The Oh My God sushi roll was wrapped in tin foil and was lit on fire when it was presented onto the table. But my noodles did not have the full, authentic flavor and taste of Japanese Udon that I have enjoyed in the past. Also, my Tempura dish did not come with Ponzu sauce, and the kitchen not have any Shichimi (Japanese chili pepper). But besides these minor downsides, the food was very fresh and everyone was satisfied with the quality of their dishes. At Miyake, the quality of the food relative to the price is great, and the reasonable prices of the dishes allow the restaurant to serve a wider range of customers. It is a fine restaurant with a wonderful venue, punctual and consistent service, and tasty Japanese food. Regardless of how many are in your party, Miyake is definitely a restaurant worth visiting. It is a restaurant with a positive reputation for its fresh ingredients and Sake bombs, and it has become a very popular dining destination for many Cornell students.", 4, 0], "IiYVzj0Hg-QDQZTaPa-3Hw": ["Yelp", "Miyake Japanese Restaurant", "9/23/2014", "Located in Ithaca, New York, Miyake offers some of the best and most Japanese dishes in town. The restaurant is indeed not cheap; however, considering the expenses the restaurant has to pay for the transportation of all the fresh ingredients to upstate New York, it is indeed not a bad deal for students who are tired of eating greasy pizzas, burgers, and fries. In addition, the quality of the food accounts for the price. Both the seafood and vegetables used in their dishes are fresh. Not only do they use fresh ingredients, Miyake is known to have some the best Japanese dishes in town making them one of the most popular restaurants among students. Due to such a positive reputation, Miyake currently supplies sushi to Mac's Caf\u00e9, located in Statler Hall, on a daily basis for Cornell students to enjoy a Japanese meal at a more convenient location. Not only does Miyake have fresh quality food, but it also has a variety of menu options. The restaurant offers a large variety of Japanese cuisine from sushi, rolls, udon, gyoza, to sashimi. Many refuse to go to restaurants with a wide range of menus believing that they don't provide quality food; yet, Miyake is different. With great cross utilization of ingredients, the restaurant offers a variety of quality gourmets that most people would enjoy. Some of the most famous dishes at Miyake include the Crazy Boy Roll and the Super Bowl. In fact, the Crazy Boy Roll is one of the most authentic dishes at Miyake where the crab and avocado sushi roll is fried and topped with savory thick soy sauce. On the other hand, the Super Bowl is a combination of assorted sashimi, lettuce, crunches, and Miyake's special sauce in a bowl creating an authentic Miyake style main course meal.Miyake not only excels in the food itself, but also in their level of service. The waiters seem to be well trained. When you first sit down at the table, the server will instantly serve you with ice water along with your menu. They also ask whether you would prefer a hot cup of green tea to melt down from the chilly weather of Ithaca. The food is then delivered about 10 minutes after ordering. When the food is served, the waiter brings over extra plates allowing you to share the food if you would like. Thus, the service at Miyake is quick and they attempt to serve any additional needs before you ask them.In addition to the great service, the d\u00e9cor of the restaurant enhances your dining experience. Miyake is not the top-notch restaurant with fancy decorations. However, the simple red and wood tone colors and the sushi bar incorporated offer a cozy traditional Japanese look and feeling. For those who place an emphasis on the sanitization of the restaurant, all the tables are wiped and the bathrooms are clean for use. Indeed, Miyake isn't a flawless restaurant. In fact, they did have some minor issues with the order in which they serve food and the saltiness. For instance, Miyake once served the main dish before the appetizer--not the best choice a restaurant could make. Yet, such mistakes could have been a one-time occurrence. One of the long-term problems of Miyake would be the saltiness of the food. Some of the plates such as the Spicy Yaki Udon and Super Bowl seemed overly salty. Especially for student from the millennial generation who attempts to eat healthier, such salty dishes are not the best attractions. Despite these minor drawbacks, Miyake is the restaurant to visit as it offers some of the best quality and fresh Japanese dishes in town along with appreciable service and menu variety.", 4, 0], "2YMYC7BdOhxZNSZGD_r9Og": ["Yelp", "Miyake Japanese Restaurant", "4/14/2014", "I only come here on Tuesdays cause they have specials for their sushi. If the service is a little slow, as other reviewers have mentioned, this is simply because there are limited sushi chefs and orders can become a bit backed up. If you come on a weekday, it is pretty unlikely that this will be an issue, since fewer people come in than on weekends and there are fewer orders to suck up time. If you do come on a weekend and are crunched for time, a good tip is that kitchen food tends to be finished faster than sushi bar fare. Coming for lunch any day is sure to cut the wait time dramatically. The Super Bowl, crazy girl roll, and OMG roll are all incredible sushi options. For kitchen food, Katsu Don is my favorite. Miyake makes a noticeable effort to have a wide variety of vegetarian options available, and there are plenty of great choices in both sushi and kitchen food. In terms of sake, Miyake has great options including the ever-fun Sake Bomb. Plum sake is my favorite. And since these involve no cooking, you will never wait for drinks!The only reason a subtracted a star was for waiting time-- which is really only an issue because the popularity of the restaurant creates a great many orders. I definitely recommend Miyake.", 4, 0], "pinhTZo5NiV4w3RdIcx0tw": ["Yelp", "Miyake Japanese Restaurant", "1/20/2013", "Miyake definitely has its highs and lows.Highs: Miyake has an extensive list of sushi rolls; for an experience, I highly recommend the \"Oh My God! {"ZSrlN9Z1IqHnzUptqY_eJg": ["Yelp", "Little Tokyo", "7/21/2006", "Don't be too tempted by the \"Half Price Rolls\" on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
