I have been to Little Tokyo two times on Thursdays and both times it was a 2+ hour ordeal. They simply don't have enough staff, but with the rather expensive state of sushi in Ithaca the half price nights still keep people coming. On my last visit I was in a party of 6 people. 5 of us had sushi and 1 ordered from the Japanese/Korean menu. The guy that ordered from the menu got his Bi Bim Bop (nothing compared to the awesome BBB at Four Seasons) in about 10min. The first sushi came out about 20min later and each order kind of trickled out over the course of another 20min. I don't know about you, but I just don't consider it acceptable to be served my dinner 40min after the first meal came out. Check it out if have time to kill and have maybe one other person with you, but don't bother trying to go with a group. Unless the sushi and service are better on the regular price nights, I wouldn't pay the full price.", 2, 1]}

{"0DVwWsL3szTv5nhvqrj7Vg": ["Yelp", "Lou\u2019s Hot Dog Stand", "10/19/2016", "For $3 it is the best decision you will make all day....provided your expectation is hot dogs, sausages or chicken spiedie char-grilled.", 5, 1], "QMB4oK81Ix4gyIYxVZEhXw": ["Yelp", "Lou\u2019s Hot Dog Stand", "9/29/2016", "Damn good hotdogs but he's pretty damn political. Then again, it is Ithaca so no surprise there.", 5, 0], "KfAnhfrCPhO9WEfxIJoz8Q": ["Yelp", "Lou\u2019s Hot Dog Stand", "6/8/2013", "This unmarked hot dog station in the middle of the Commons right outside of Bank of America is an Ithaca fixture. They serve classic all beef, grilled, hot dogs with any of the following items kosher New York City sauerkraut, freshly grilled onions and peppers, spicy pepper relish, onions, classic pickle relish, Nancy's mustard, and of course ketchup and yellow mustard. They even have veal dogs, Italian pork sausages, and chicken spiedies (grilled chicken cubes in a hotdog bun -- spiedies are an upstate NY invention). I have tried all of these options and they are all fantastic, but I am a purest and love the kosher all beef dog with grilled peppers and a touch of sauerkraut the best. You can also purchase frito-lay bags of chips and bottled/canned drinks.He uses local wieners ...tee hee....from Hofmann's franks based out of Syracuse New York. Lou notes that he thinks that \"central New Yorkers prefer the grilled flavor to the classic New York city steamed or boiled hot dogs.\" This is why he switched to a gas powered grill in 2001. I can't agree more, I love the grill.Lou is super friendly, and he'll chat with you as he prepares your dogs. Its $2 per hot dog. One dog is a great snack, 2 dogs or 1 chicken spiedie is a great meal. I never \"plan\" to eat here as the hours are dependent on the wether, I usually see them while walking around the commons and can't resist.", 5, 7]}

Not sure about the price since I was here for an event.The layout is nice for private meetings.", 4, 2], "vd04lrUCrMLke-cNmfyNWQ": ["Yelp", "Taverna Banfi", "11/18/2008", "Largely, I agree with the previous reviews, their complaints, and their compliments. If you are on Cornell's campus as a visitor of some kind and are thus more or less limited to the campus proper, or if you are meeting visitors, this is pretty much the place to take them. Out of my affection for Ithaca and its dining scene, I'd question the statement that this is \"one of a few 'fancy' restaurants\" in town. No, there might not be as many as in, say, San Francisco, but I can think of a good handful, and for a town of Ithaca's size, what more would you expect? If you want fancy, or are looking to impress someone, and can make it to John Thomas or The Heights, by all means do so. But Banfi's will work in a pinch if you are on campus.I've only been for dinner once, and I suppose the conditions predisposed me to having a positive experience regardless...it was free, on the tab of some alumni. The food, in my opinion, was quite good; I started with a goat cheese, prosciutto, and apricot flatbread, followed by the duck two ways (confit and roasted breast), and finished with a flourless chocolate torte. No complaints here, everything was as expected and delicious, with no errors in preparation or presentation. I'm not sure what I was thinking ordering duck confit in a Tuscan restaurant, but it turned out well. My tablemates had varying experiences: several were less than impressed with the strip steak, one approved of the rack of lamb, and another raved about that night's Chilean sea bass special. I've also heard concensus reports from others that their gnocchi and pasta dishes are excellent, and I would generally say that, given the theme of the place, these would always be safe bets. The wine list was extensive, and the server, while a student (yes, this is at a university, to those of you who seem surprised by this), was very knowledgeable. I will say that the service was EXTREMELY slow even though there was not much of a crowd. I don't know what they were doing in the kitchen but they were doing it slowly. Prices were generally high, expect to pay a lot for not much food.So you may be wondering why four stars at this point, and I hope I haven't lost the readers' attention. Because, the reason for those four stars, a reason which none of the previous reviewers have mentioned, in fact the true reason why Banfi's is even popular within the student community, is the Sunday brunch. This is one of Cornell's true gems, and attending is in fact is one of the 161 things every Cornellian should do (you have to charge it to Cornellcard for it to count though!). Every other possible experience you could have here pales in comparison to this.Brunch is held starting at 11 AM each Sunday. Depending on what's going on on campus, you might want reservations, or the place might have been booked 2 years ago (homecoming, graduation, etc). Most weekends it's no big deal. You walk in, they show you to your table, and they let you at it. Service isn't an issue this time, because all they are doing is clearing out the plates as fast as you can mow through them. Cost is $20 per person; for $9 you can add a bottomless champagne flute if it's after noon and you want to have some fun. The selection of foods is vast, and covers the gamut of basically all the breakfast and lunch foods you could expect. In the center is a wide selection of cold salads, usually including things such as a buffalo mozzerella and tomato salad, a salmon and caper salad (delicious), couscous salads, and a whole bunch of other constantly changing selections. To the right are the cold breakfast foods, including a full selection of pastries, bagels, flavored spreads, fresh fruits, yogurt, a good selection of imported cheeses, smoked salmon, and peel-and-eat shrimp. For the hot selections, there are usually about six breakfast choices, including belgian waffles, pancakes, excellent sausages, grits, eggs, and the usually. Additionally, there are usually about five lunch entree selections, which in the past have included four cheese ravioli with vodka sauce (very good), mahi mahi with red pepper sauce, bouillabaisse, carved lamb, and prime rib. Dessert is the best part, as I usually eat enough to make back the cost right there. There are usually about six selections, and if the concept of all-you-can-eat creme brulee doesn't strike your fancy, I don't know what will. Overall, the variety is very good, and the quality is excellent. This is what they are famous for and they go all out for it. So, in short, go for brunch, you won't be disappointed.", 4, 5], "65E5QmR5zlJwhzHJkoDudw": ["Yelp", "Taverna Banfi", "11/9/2007", "Don't go here for dinner. The soy sauce was off, smelled vaguely of cheap alcohol, and tasted like it was mixed with some kind of marinade. The tempura had an alternately meaty and lemony flavor, despite what had to be fresh fryer oil. The rich toro and avocado roll, which should have come alive with a hit of salt, was instead ruined by the odd soy sauce, and woefully tasteless without it. It does not worth the price.", 3, 0], "I7ay6Z3eV3Ltrt7T1XSzbA": ["Yelp", "Plum Tree Restaurant", "1/31/2017", "Pretty mediocre sushi in the heart of Collegetown. Definitely not a place for an extravagant meal or date, but hits the spot for sake bombs and cheap dinner with a large group. At $10 per, the sake bombs are a pretty decent deal. Some favorites for dinner include the chicken katsu and the fried rice, which at under $10 each make for a cheap dinner. The dinner bento boxes are pricey but can be easily shared between two people if you aren't too hungry, and I believe they're about half price at lunch.Service is reliably average, and the restaurant is consistently clean. Typically never a problem getting a table without a reservation, but periodically there will be a date night or event at Plum Tree that makes it difficult to get in on short notice, especially with a large group. They have a sort of 'lofted' area to the restaurant where they usually seat larger parties. Can be loud on certain nights when there are large parties (usually Fridays or Saturdays at 8 ish).Splitting a check a bunch of ways can be kind of a nightmare at Plum Tree, which is surprising because of how many large parties they do. Not because it is an amazing restaurant, but out of desperation as it is by far the best in the Cornell area that one can get to without a car. Plum Tree has OK food. It certainly hits the spot for any who are clamoring for yummy Japanese or Asian food such as katsu chicken, takoyaki, sashimi, etc. One thing to note is that they have something called a Salmon Don which is a plate of only salmon sashimi (10 pieces) but it doesn't seem to be listed on the main menu, only menus through Ithaca to Go and such. You can also switch out your salad for a miso soup if you want for free which is really nice. However, none of the food is spectacular; most of the rolls are rather overpriced for the amount and quality you get, the fish isn't fresh and on some days you may get large slices, other days the portions may be very small. Also they overcharge, but everywhere in Ithaca does this. They do their best at hosting large parties, and do seem to have a good system down pat for hosting large parties. However, their waiters appear to have frequently struggled getting orders for large parties correct, or even parties as little as 4 people...I can remember several times off the top of my head my waiter has brought the wrong thing, and even suggested that I ordered something else. That said, this usually all gets corrected as the manager is a wonderful lady who does try to do best by her customers. They feature a sushi bar near the front of the restaurant and larger group seating in the \"second level\". The location is convenient for Ithaca's student population being right below Collegetown Plaza, across the street from Eddygate, and half a block down from Collegetown Center. It doesn't have much of an authentically Asian vibe to it.Food Review --Plum Tree has a great selection of rolls, sashimi, and warm udon dishes. I have previously tried the 007 roll and a couple others here for dinner, so this time I decided to try my luck with the lunch boxes (served between 11:30am and 2:30pm). At the low price of $9.95, I assumed that if it turned out badly, not too much harm could come of it.From a long list of lunch specials I ordered the chicken katsu, lightly breaded and fried chicken. It came with rice, a small salad, two fried dumplings, a handful of edamame beans, and four pieces of an avocado roll. It was already looking like a got a bang for my buck! The breading on the katsu was a little overcooked, resulting in slightly dry and overly crispy chicken.A friend of mine got the spicy tuna & salmon roll combo and she was kind enough to let me swipe a couple off her plate. I was pleasantly surprised by the ratio of rice to fish in each bite. Plum Tree doesn't skimp on the sushi filling. The spicy tuna also had a nice kick to it.Service Review --Our waiter was very quick with taking our order and then he vanished. Luckily, one of the guys I've seen working there is always cheerful enough and he gave us a big smile and cheerful \"hello\" and \"goodbye\" in Japanese (I'm assuming) as we left.Overall Impression --Competing with Miyake for the best sushi in town, I'd have to say that Plum Tree is my favorite of the two. Although a little pricey with some of their items, Plum Tree's lunch special will not make a dent in your wallet and still leave you feeling pretty full. Although Miyake does have a tasty signature dish, their Super Bowl, it goes for an outrageous $17.95 and with tax & tip you end up forking over a ridiculous $20+. It's been hit and miss for me at Plum Tree when it comes to food, but if you're looking for a good place to Sake Bomb, this is the spot. {"TuPhB-0tRXCfZMx4iAUnwA": ["Yelp", "The Sub Shop", "7/8/2014", "Okay, so this is the business listing for a sub shop, which is a little strange, but it's one of very few places to get a sandwich in town without having to drive to another town. There are also a few small booths inside if you're not taking your eats elsewhere. When you pull up, the place looks like a dilapidated shack house, and I guess it still looks like that when you go inside. The small dining/waiting area is surrounded by bookshelves covered with books for sale - each priced around $1. They appeared to be highlighting a soft-cover copy of 50 shades of grey on my visit. Hang a left when you enter and place your order with the guy on the grill behind the shelving. Pay after you receive your food. If you show up with the intention of ordering take out, expect a wait, as most other customers will have called in their orders. The food is standard backwoods sub shop fare. The cook used either a microwave or toaster about 7 different times before our order (two salads and a tuna sub) came out. Not sure what for. Price was reasonable at least, and the salad greens weren't rotten. Not many fresh veggie options, and adding more toppings will cost you. Canned mushrooms? I think I'll pass. If you're going to be in Lansing, and are starving, come here, or hit up the gas station on the way to Myer's point. They also have a deli counter. If you want something delicious, drive to Ithaca and hit up Wegmans. Their subs look and taste fantastic.", 3, 7]}

Ten minutes later our waitress came back with just one of our dishes, and the wrong one, at that (tofu was used in place of chicken). We sent the dish back and after a total of over an hour of waiting, the crowd in the restaurant had completely died down.... Alas, only then did we get all of our food and a brief apology from our waitress. By that time, the table seated after us had already eaten finished their meal and was headed out. Our food was alright, though nothing to write home about. However, my friend who is vegetarian noted that she ate a small piece of chicken in her tofu Pad Thai. Thankfully she is vegetarian by choice and doesn't have any serious adverse reactions from consuming chicken so we didn't want to make it a serious ordeal by complaining to the staff.The biggest joke of the night however, was when waitress told us that the 18% gratuity is mandated by the establishment when she handed us our check, probably knowing the service overall was sh*t but still wanting to be compensated for it. I decided to complain to the manager, expecting him to be sympathetic. While he did eventually take the gratuity off our tab, he first gave me a small lecture on the purpose of gratuity. Not appreciating his condescension, I repeated that the gratuity paid should reflect the service received and then I brought up the fact that my vegetarian friend had a piece of chicken in her dish. He replied it was impossible given the way he runs his kitchen. Listen, I don't go to restaurants to nit-pick at service or lie about the food I receive, and I certainly don't go looking to argue with restaurant managers about the way they run their kitchens; I go to eat. While I don't believe the old adage \"the customer is always right\" is in fact always right, any respectable restaurant manager should respect their customer's word. My friends and I paid and left, thoroughly disappointed with Taste of Thai. If you're looking for a place to eat, go anywhere else and if all other establishments are packed, you might as well go to a supermarket like Wegman's for their already prepared foods because Taste of Thai's is certainly not worth the trouble. The curries and noodle dishes are business as usual, good but not fantastic.The spiciness scale (1-5), is really inconsistent here. In general though, I think 1-3 means almost no spice at all (warning: I have heard some people who don't like spice complain about a 3 being too hot but I honestly can't tell the difference most of the time between a 1 and a 3 here). The difference between a 3 (still almost no spice) and a 4 (medium hot) is pretty drastic. A 5, my preferred choice, is reasonably spicy but not insane. Kind of a cop out as a garnish or complement to the dish.For entrees, I had the pineapple curry (w/ veg) which was once again, nothing special. My mother had the emerald green curry (w/beef) which was far too salty. My boyfriend had one of the fried noodle dishes and boy were those rice noodles over cooked. Limp, mushy, and greasy. Luckily, this time there were more vegetables + meat than noodles. We each requested our dish to be a Level 3 spicy. Now, typically at Taste of Thai Express, a Level 3 spicy is very, very hot. It is Thai level spicy, not American level spicy. At Taste of Thai however, Level 3 barely registered to us, and we all LOVE spicy food.Our original waitress also never returned to ask us how our food was, so we had to flag down a different waitress and ask her for extra hot condiments.Overall, the experience was unremarkable and I highly doubt I will ever return. And I don't think I've had tastier duck curry anywhere else, and I eat a lot of Thai food. I love the mix of rich and subtle flavors of this dish: the sharper taste of fresh green bell peppers mingling with the softer, more rounded flavors of the red and yellow ones over basic eggplant (cooked so it is not too soggy, not too hard) and juicy grape tomato. Then there are the added tones of tangy grapes, sweet lychee, and citrus-y pineapple prepared with red curry past. Everything is smoothed over by the coconut milk into one well-balanced entree. Awesome. I've tried other dishes here also: the pad-thai (go-to thai noodle dish), pad-see eew (also a noodle dish), the choo-chee (fish in red curry), the khao pad sapparod (pineapple fried rice), and various curry dishes. All of them were good; I was never disappointed. Some of the appetizers are pretty good too (especially the som tum: papaya salad). Note: the spring rolls are really, really hot when they come out, so yes, they're wonderfully fresh, but will burn the crap out of your mouth. I starving when they got to the table the first time I ordered them, so I crunched into them right away, and, let me tell you, it wasn't pretty... but it was so, so goooood.... One thing I didn't like about Taste of Thai was that, while this place is good, some dishes are a bit more than I would usually pay for. It tasted like chicken and didn't have a huge amount of flavor though it was very moist and fell right off the bone which was great.The chili they had wasn't very spicy even though they had a \"spicy\" sign on it. The Pakora was deep fried veggies with a huge amount of seasoning that blew me away. I tasted cumin, curry, salt and a few other spices that were just amazing. It was crazy good though and I could eat these all day!The curry potatoes were good too which tasted like traditional cumin and curry homefries.The dessert sticky rice I wasn't a huge fan of, it was sweet but there was a flavor that was just off to me.Overall this was a pretty decent lunch and I'd definitely go back for a lunch but I don't think I would go out of my way to come back and it's not because the food wasn't good it's just because after eating here I realized I'm not a huge fan of the traditional cumin and curry flavors but the food was cooked great.The service, atmosphere and price were really good as well. Go big or go home is the motto, so we picked this Indian Buffet.The Grub --* Mehak Lunch Special Buffet ($9.28 Incl. Tip & Tax)Venue Review --Just outside the heart of Collegetown, Mehak is on quiet little Eddy Street next to Level B. It's a simple enough restaurant, as you enter you'll see the buffet is ten feet ahead of you and there's two and four person seating on your left and right. Basically a rectangle, the layout is very simple and conducive to buffet style eating without requiring much weaving between tables.Food Review --There's no way you can go wrong with Indian food, or at least that's my philosophy. A lot of the time, you'll have no idea what you're eating because it's bathed in spices, curry and mouthfuls of flavor, but sometimes that's what all the excitement's about! I snapped a few photos of my plates, featuring items such as chicken tikka masala, shahi butter chicken, pindi chana masala, garlic nan, and aloo saag. At Mehak they always have the freshest ingredients and more than enough food to satisfy the hungriest carnivore and/or herbivore. Vegeterian options galore.Service Review --It's a buffet, so you can't expect much service, but what the waitstaff did provide (refills and check service) was friendly and speedy.Overall Impression --This was only my second time here in the past year, but like the last visit, it ended with a belly full of warm food and a comfortable food coma. I'll definitely be visiting more often because the restaurant is not only delicious but extremely affordable for a college student. The only other Indian buffet is a little farther up the street (Sangam Indian Cuisine), but Mehak is too good to risk disappointment at another venue.Here's a quote concerning Indian food from one of my favorite movies, ANCHORMAN:\"Veronica Corningstone: My God, what is that smell? Just make sure you wear something you don't mind getting dirty (in case you spill curry or something, it never comes off) and mind getting smelly (I smelled like Indian food all day).", 4, 20], "4a5NvmREcqvp5_BHTs86Sg": ["Yelp", "Mehak Cuisine", "10/18/2010", "In any big city, Mehak would be a good, solid restaurant. But in a small town like Ithaca, Mehak goes above and far beyond my expectations. If I could, I would give Mehak 4.5 stars for excellent service, great taste, and calm ambiance.I came here for Mehak's grand opening and I tried the lunch buffet. I'll admit, I was not impressed. I wasn't disappointed either. My feelings about the place were lukewarm at best. But recently, my boyfriend and I were hit by a mad craving for Indian food. His housemate raved about Mehak, so I decided, desperate times called for giving this place another try. And let me say: I am SO GLAD we did.SERVICE: We walked in, were greeted with a smile, seated, and immediately provided with water (mark of attentive staff). When I put down my menu to indicate I was ready to order, I saw that the waiter took notice, put down the pile of menus he was organizing, and immediately make his way to our table to take our order. I made a lot of \"ums\" and \"uhs\" about what I wanted, but despite my take-backs and additions, he got the order perfectly: 2 vegetable samosas, black pepper pappadums, chicken tikka masala (I always order this at Indian places to get a feel for the quality of the basics), chicken vindaloo, garlic naan, masala chai, and mango lasse. (We were HUNGRY!) When we finished the meal, the super nice waitress was quick to clean the table, offer us more drinks, share a few laughs, and hand us the check. Awesome.FOOD:Let's just talk about the food off the menu. The naan was amazing: soft, fluffy, with perfect consistency and wonderful over-baked flavor served steaming hot. Samosas were spicy, crispy on the outside and bursting with flavor on the inside; the chutneys definitely help with decided how much more spice you want. Pappadums were also spicy; you could see the lentils baked into it, and the black pepper was a perfect, light addition to the crispy wafers. The chicken tikka masala was very tomato-y but in a good way; there was the tang of actual tomatoes underneath the creamy curry. The chicken vindaloo was spicier and definitely has the flavors of the malt vinegar instead of red wine or whatever curry is usually paired with. Both the chicken and the potatoes were perfectly marinated in the sauce. Mango lasse? Amazing! The yogurt was more dominant at first, but as you drank it, the mango really came out. Super refreshing for such a creamy drink. And the chai was exactly what I wanted on a cold Ithaca night. As you can tell, I tasted quite a bit of food from Mehak. The thing is, the menu is quite large and I will be sure to go back to try more of it! ATMOSPHERE: Chill. I felt like I could relax there; the staff was attentive but not pushy and I felt like I could eat at my leisure, add items to my order, or ask for a refill. I liked the bollywood music playing the background because it added to the feel of the place without making it difficult to hold conversation. Everything was clean and neatly organized. Presentation of the food was simple but effective. Nicely done. VERDICT:Definitely give this place a try if you're interested in well-balanced flavors and excellent service!", 4, 17], "E17LXzdqTFesXccPd10Gig": ["Yelp", "Mehak Cuisine", "10/10/2010", "Mehak has the best Indian food in Ithaca!My husband and I had dinner here tonight with friends and their baby girl. I replied \"allergies, but it is also my preference.\" The cashier had a conversation later with my friend when she asked her why such an odd question was being asked to anyone ordering vegan dishes. My friend wondered if they were conducting a survey of some sort. The cashier replied that they cook the \"allergy\" vegan items on a dedicated vegan waffle maker, but those ordered for simply \"preference\" were cooked on the same waffle makers as the non-vegan waffles. I find it unconscionable that a restaurant offering vegan options would knowingly contaminate dishes ordered by strict vegans with dairy or eggs. There should be no difference between the preparation of a vegan waffle for allergy or ethical reasons and it felt invasive to be questioned that way. So. Many. Choices. I stopped by here with my Vegan friendly. Now I understand many places in Ithaca are vegan or vegetarian friendly and when you think of a waffle joint, beef or chicken (yuck) don't come to mind, eggs maybe, but not beef or chicken. However, what sets Waffle Frolic aside from many other Ithaca eateries (who are more so Vegan accommodating) is that Waffle Frolic labels everything that is Vegan or Vegetarian. On top of that, they have a vegan ice cream. I mean come on. My vegan friend's eye lit up when we walked in. Never mind the forever existing line for a Sunday morning. The shop has a simple and straightforward menu. You walk in and you follow the easy steps: pick a waffle (gf/vegan options available), pick a size (single or twin) and then pick your toppings. Indecisive? No prob. They have tons of pre-\"arranged\" waffle meals including chicken with waffle (next on my list to try), waffle with two eggs and bacon (yum), grilled cheese, turkey chili with a cornbread waffle, and they always have some specials. The day I went, they had a hangover waffle (with everything but the kitchen sink) and a florentine waffle. We went during brunch hour so the line was long but it is so worth it. Once you order, head upstairs to grab a seat. It is definitely first come first serve and if you get there at the wrong time, you might just need to grab a seat outside on one of the benches in the Commons. I settled on a single eggs and bacon (it's brunch after all) and then a single buttermilk waffle with Nutella and fruit of the day (strawberry). My friend got the twin with vegan ice cream. We were stuffed. I also want to mention they have drinks available. We each went for heir chai latte. They even have drink substitutes for their drinks. The only thing hey did not have that I feel could have been made was vegan whipped cream, but no biggie at all.I would say the waffle was very light, fluffy on the inside, crispy to the bite. My savory waffle worked really nicely--I was concerned they wouldn't time the temperature of all the components right, but it was perfect. The eggs were cooked over easy and my bacon crispy but not burt. As a waffle iron owner, I was definitely impressed with the flavor packed meal. My classic Nutella and strawberry waffle also did not disappoint. My vegan friend and I spent much of the first 15 minutes eating. Our lattes were delicious.Finally, I would say they have a loud speaker installed so they can call your name and you can come down to pick up the food by the front counter on the first floor. Large waffles in two sizes (single and twin... Don't worry, there are actual size pictures near the menu to help make your choice). made fresh to order with choice of batter and toppings are all a recipe for delicious success.The establishment is split between two levels. The ground floor is the kitchen and ordering space, and upstairs is entirely filled with seating. Small silver tables with matching chairs allow for small groups to gather or for larger ones to pull together and perhaps play one of the board games available. It's a bit well used looking, feeling like a combination of mini school cafeteria and a friend's house's basement hangout.Waffles. Great for breakfast, brunch, lunch or snack. I had a single hearty hemp and buckwheat waffle with peanut butter and honey. Delicious! The waffle was lightly crispy outside with a warm fluffy inside. The peanut butter was drizzled across generously without completely drowning the waffle, and there was a good pour of honey to taste without sending me into a diabetic coma. My boyfriend had a twin buttermilk with chocolate sauce and strawberries. I'm thoroughly impressed at how they heaped whole fresh strawberries onto the order. Turkey chili and waffle sound like a match made in heaven.Orders are taken along with your name which is broadcast over speakers upstairs and downstairs when ready. The \"truck\" is actually a trailer that turns into a glowing box at night, and its sleek minimalist aesthetic would be completely at home in a hip design district of a major world city. Its cuisine is almost at the same level. Good noodle dishes and passable dosas (a rarity in Ithaca) make for a nice blend of pan-Asian dishes, with some Mexican options as well, including a delicious hibiscus agua fresca. Nothing here is as good as you might find in an \"authentic\" Vietnamese, Indian, or Mexican restaurant, but it's really, really good for a food truck in rural upstate New York that's making a stab at preparing dishes from all three cuisines. The opening hours (til 9, which is really convenient for those who work late on campus) are helpful, too.", 4, 1]}

I've actually been known to come here right before a final, order some food, and walk to the final while eating. Filled my stomach but didn't do much for my grades. My only complaint was that the service was sooooo slow!!!!!!!!!!!! If they can fix that it would be A-ok", 4, 1], "Tt423VRe9wCJHt4rYAv59w": ["Yelp", "Sahara Mediterranean Restaurant", "4/1/2012", "I regularly travel to Qatar, and have middle eastern roots. The culinary incentive for my trips has largely vanished with the opening of Sahara. Their Syrian/Middle Eastern cuisine is authentic and excellent. Spice level is on the milder side. The grilled meats are lean, delicious and authentically seasoned. The grilled pita bread (at least the white version; I haven't tried the whole wheat, because for middle eastern food that's just wrong . . .) doesn't taste and feel like cardboard (an Ithaca first . . .). Although they don't spit-roast their chicken, their chicken shawarma pita is delicious. My wife rarely eats meat. Sahara's version of foules mesdames - a traditional bean dish - is by far the best I've had anywhere. Their labneh - a thick yogurt appetizer - is also superb, especially eaten with baba ganoush or hummos and pita. The tabouleh is fresh, delicate and light - unlike what you get in food bars; ask for the dressing on the side. The falafels are tasty and crunchy, although I prefer the softer, more heavily seasoned version at the Corners Deli. The middle eastern desserts - baklava, kunafa, basbosa - are all home made, fresh tasting and light - not sickly sweet, syrup soaked and soggy as in most middle eastern restaurants. For someone used to the rice pudding at diners, Wegman's and Cornell, Sahara's rice pudding is a revelation. The portions are generous (as in the middle east), and the pricing - especially of the appetizers, pitas and desserts, is extremely reasonable. The wait-staff are young, likely students. They do their best, but as at most Ithaca restaurants, don't expect the experienced professionalism of, e.g., the Heights or John Thomas. In terms of its execution of a particular cuisine, Sahara may be Ithaca's best restaurant. It is without doubt the best middle eastern restaurant in Central New York.", 5, 1], "GUlTdyNr48LXL9HqlY74JA": ["Yelp", "Sahara Mediterranean Restaurant", "3/24/2012", "While the food was not bad at all (meat was tender, veggies fresh), the service could certainly be improved. {"GvZ7_19M_KJICsitqVfOGw": ["Yelp", "Old Mexico", "1/12/2019", "Ithaca is not known for good Mexican food, and the existence of Old Mexico does not help its culinary landscape. I ate there tonight for the first time and attempted their steak street tacos. They were terrible -- I ate only 2 of the 4 tacos (one of my companions only managed to stomach 1 of hers), and tried only a mouthful each of the beans and rice. The steak was dry, there were way too many raw onions on the tacos, and the salsa and beans came from a can (although I do think they threw some fresh cilantro into the salsa).The service was not much better. While the hostess was friendly and seated us quickly, the server took far too long to take our orders or even acknowledge us. When I told her that I could not eat any gluten, seemed unwilling to make note of that for the kitchen (she merely told me corn does not have gluten. As someone with Celiac's Disease, I know that; I wanted to ensure that they didn't use stocks or sauces with gluten in them, shared friers, etc.). Starting off with the chicken and waffles, the chicken was very crispy in contrast with the very soft waffle. There was less chicken than I had expected though. The sausage was mediocre and it was small too. Probably my least favourite part. The biscuits and gravy were a new try for me but the white gravy was way too salty for my tastes. All in all, everything was average and nothing really stood out to me.On the other hand, their staff are very friendly and made sure we had our waters topped up and new utensils when we needed them. We also had a nice chat with her which was very pleasant. Good thing we split the food, as everything was pretty expensive. The chicken and waffles was $20, the sausage which I could finish in 3 bites was $7 and the biscuit was around $15. I felt like it wasn't particularly filling even after sharing 3 dishes.Overall, my experience here was OK. I didn't get to try too many places in the area so there was not much to compare to. The State Diner delivers on what you would expect out of a typical American diner. (10/15/16)Food 4/5 | Atmosphere 3/5 | Service 5/5 | Value 3/5Pros: good variety of food, great service, friendly staffCons: some meals have more value than others, price matches quality of food but not atmosphere----Food 4/5: (Tuna Melt w/ Fries $10, Souvlaki w/ feta cheese $9)I ordered the Tuna Melt on rye bread with fries, and was pleasantly surprised at how good it was. I always order the tuna option when I eat sandwiches, and let me tell you, this tuna melt was one of the best I've ever had. The rye bread (with hints of dill) was perfectly toasted with butter. The tuna salad itself was a perfect consistency-- not too dry, not too wet. The thick cut of swiss cheese with the pickle on the side made the dish complete. The fries were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside; well seasoned.My partner ordered the Souvlaki with feta ($1 extra) and no tomatoes. The pork was well-cooked and seasoned-- not overly salty as some souvlakis can be. There was a good sauce to meat ratio, but there was too much lettuce on top. The pita bread was soft yet had the firm chewy texture one would expect from a good souvlaki. The tzatziki sauce itself was creamy with the right amount of garlic and spices. Combined with the sprinkling of feta cheese on top, the dish struck the right balance between tart and creamy.Atmosphere 3/5The booth seats can be a little uncomfortable, as they flip up, but are playful and adds a rough charm to the place. The music can be a little loud, and depending on your partiality to the style of the music itself, can get a bit much. However, it's still a great atmosphere if you like classic Americana diners. The place feels like a nostalgic timepiece of the past but renovated to accommodate modern needs. Ultimately, it's a place to \"hang out\" but not \"go out.\"Service 5/5Attentive and friendly staff. Provided refills without prompting. Asked how we were going mid-way. Provided us the check without having to call, and proactively asked if we wanted to split or pay the check together. Upon leaving, we were given a friendly and genuine \"have a great day.\" Overall, we were impressed by the attentiveness of the service staff.Value 3/5Some items have greater value and are more filling than others (the tuna melt with fries + pickle at $10 vs. just souvlaki w/ feta cheese $9), but ultimately the prices are fair. A quick drive through darkened and quiet streets brought us to the bright neon sign of the State Diner.The place was very quiet - only two patrons. What do you expect on a summer night? We picked a booth, and plopped down [with difficulty, given the relatively narrow booths with folding seats (!) and 5'8\" and 6'2\" frames we represent].  The environment is a typical \"grease spoon\", without the chrome, mirrors and rotating dessert showcases of the overdone diners. A well-used counter, where many-a-patron enjoyed a quick omelet, sandwich or a cup of coffee with a piece of pie. It's a neighborhood dive that is a reliable stand-by at any hour of the day or night.But, I guess, since the school year is out and it's pretty slow, the service was also quite slow... I am pretty sure x is greater than 30, so that means there are at least 110 million possible salads. It is hard to do a lot of things well. I got a copy of the new menu and it looks like most the dishes that have been praised in the reviews will be staying.During my most recent visit we ordered three dishes and shared them, family style, the way you are supposed to. My friend doesn't like spicy or too weird but there are so many things on the menu that I haven't tried, that wasn't a problem. We ordered the Angelica Lamb Soup, the Sauteed Baby Bok Choy, and the Crispy Chicken w. House Special SauceOne order of Angelica Lamb Soup is enough for four people. It is chunks of lamb with sliced angelica root in a savory broth. The lamb has skin and bits of bones. It seems to be a belly or rib cut. The Angelica root is pale and tastes a little like bitter carrot. Angelica is a medicinal plant and tastes bitter. If you don't like bitter herbs don't try this. But lots of people do like bitter herbs.Bok choy is also a little bitter. The sauteed bok choy had lots of sliced garlic and a mild savory sauce. Even with the large quantities of garlic it was not too spicy for my friend. The Crispy Chicken came with a sweet vinegar sauce that was a nice complement to the bitter herbs. The chicken was lightly dusted with cornstarch or flour and fried until crispy, and the sauce was light and tangy. It came with a side of rice for each of us. I don't order sweet and sour chicken at restaurants because the batter is usually too thick and greasy and the sauce is corn syrup and food coloring. But this Crispy Chicken was what sweet and sour chicken should taste like. We also had milk tea with tapioca pearls. My friend had peach flavored and I had green apple. My Chinese friend said that it's a pretty common black tea that you have at the end of the meal. I thought it tasted a bit different from normal black tea because it has a subtle sweet after taste and really great aroma. And lucky me, the prices are still low (for now anyway!)It seemed like this place popped up almost instantly after CT Bento closed, so I didn't expect much in the way of interior changes. But they did a nice job with the few things they did - they put in some booths, created some half walls which divides up the space nicely, and they closed off the kitchen. And the special sushi rolls are soooo good and so well presented. Like Bento, they have the make your own bowls with different meats/veg/sauces, and still have that super addictive bubble tea. Lunch specials are something like $6.50 and come with either a soup or an eggroll, and white/brown/or chicken fried rice. It's a lot of food for these crazy cheap prices! And it wasn't really love at first. The decor is okay, the environment is relaxing. The dark ambience works well for dinners, but makes the place seem slightly sketchy during lunch service. The lunch buffet, which is what most people know them for, is okay if you know what you like, but lacks focus and can fill you up quickly with things you wished you hadn't tried. The service is very inconsistent and generally worsens during peak hours. Once I called in a takeout and arrived half an hour later to find that they never put my order in the kitchen! !?! They didn't apologize for the mix-up and pretended nothing was wrong.But service aside, you can find some real gems among the dishes. I first fell in love with Sangam after a friend introduced me to their lamb korma. It was so amazing I thought about it for a week afterward, my mouth watering with lust. Another time, I tried a friend's shrimp saag and again, my mouth mourned for days afterward, missing the warm comfort of gooey spinach mingled with fresh shrimp. Their fluffy and fragrant basmati rice makes a great compliment to any dish. The meat samosas are better than the vegetable counterparts and make tasty appetizers if you're ever pressed for time hosting a dinner party. Sangam is a great place to eat if you're with friends and have a good idea of what you really like. Don't count on the service and be prepared to wait awhile if they're busy. For orders to go, walk in and order instead of trying to call ahead. If you're new to the gig, give the lamb korma and samosas a try ... mmmm.", 4, 99]}

Despite being cheap, especially by my standards which are used to NYC prices, I still think Aladdin's is overpriced. The pitas are a decent deal at around $7 a piece, but they don't come with any sides and end up being not super filling. Plus, even in the city you pay $3-$4 for a better pita from a cart, so it's hard to justify getting one at Aladdin's. The pasta dishes run you around $12-14 AND there's an upcharge of around $4 to add meat AND an upcharge for certain types of pasta, so you can easily drop close to $20 for a pasta dish. Granted, the portions are huge, but not enough to justify the price for what is (let's be honest) probably sauce from a jar over boxed pasta. Last time I went, my friend and I split the cheese pita appetizer, which was literally just cheese melted on a pita for $5.50 and reminded me a lot of food that I've made when I stumble home from the bar at 3 in the morning.The drinks - here's one area where Aladdin's excels - the drink menu is relatively large, and extremely cheap. Beers will run you $4 or so at the most and those aren't happy hour prices. They have a deal where you can get 2 bottles of wine for $20 during certain times, and they have a $14 (albeit terrible) bottle of white sangria on the menu which they serve in cute glasses with fruit. The service - oddly terrible every time I go. I'm not sure if I've just had really bad luck, but I've had multiple waitresses with nasty attitudes that aren't attentive at all. Thus, let us assay the Rhine House with a most critical and discerning eye. First, we must acknowledge that a bar's aesthetic is the very soul of its being. Thusly, to delineate both the intent and consequence of an aesthetic--and to determine their alignment--is to unmask the de facto efficacy of said establishment. In this sense, we find the Rhine House situated firmly and unabashedly in its ethos - neither pretentious nor unnecessarily humble, the aesthetic belies the very same earnestness of its soul. One of its patrons (on which I shall speak presently) might refer to such an atmosphere as \"Fine, whatever. Just a local bar,\" by which we can corroborate that it is indeed the very quintessence of candid self-actualization... the ding an sich.Next, it is only fitting that we turn to the common patronage of an establishment in order to gain a sense of its proverbial terroir. For what else is a bar if not the corporeal presence of a community's ethereal (though nonetheless substantial) identity? If the Rhine House is any microcosm of its greater community, then it does the town a service in its facade. Eschewing whatever negative connotations we might attach to a meaningless label of \"diversity,\" the actual diversity of the Rhine House's clientele is a refreshing slice of humanity's imperfections and accomplishments alike. Were I a layman, unconcerned with the ambiguities of clich\u00e9 adages, I might daresay the place is down-to-earth.Penultimately, let us recognize that the staff of this establishment have little tolerance for nonsense and a large tolerance for everything else. Should an inebriated hooligan attempt to incite a furor among those around him, I have little doubt that s/he would be dealt with swiftly and uncompromisingly (for the good of the order, of course). Conversely, the same barkeeps do well to humor others in their trivial conversations, no matter how many iterations of the same topics and questions have been drunkenly thrown at their direction, perhaps in an attempt at quelling--or at least fleetingly mitigating--the encroaching loneliness of life. Finally, it would only be fitting to note the variety of spirits available and the financial burdens thereunto. Stated plainly, the variety of ales and liquors is adequate; the variety of wines is unsurprisingly limited, yet considerable in quality. Among all options, cost is no greater factor than one should expect (at worst) or, on some nights and for some particular libations, exceedingly fair (at best). In total, I would estimate that all manners of person from all manners of occupation could afford both the literal cost and the company involved in such an outing.Please pardon any errors or idiosyncrasies in this screed - English is but my eighth language.P.S. (see:http://www.fatfreekitchen.com/junkfoods/mcdonald-ingredients.html)and it's not \"Vanilla\", it's Vanilla-ish, or vanilla-like, or more commonly vanilla-flavored. It's that simple. But I am not impressed by this place anymore.", 3, 0], "zh7aQCO7WUOvXDK4HoVWqw": ["Yelp", "Taste of Thai Express", "8/24/2015", "I have been here twice with my friend. Both times I ordered the Chicken pad see ew, so I guess that tells you how I feel about the dish. Chicken pad see ew is a broad noodle dish with their Thai broccoli, soy sauce and yellow bean paste. This is my go-to dish aside from pad thai when I try a new Thai restaurant. Since the noodles are broader, it is easier to make the dish very greasy (more oil makes it easer to saut\u00e9). However, this dish was not only not greasy, it was well seasoned and the Thai broccoli gave it a delicious texture. At my second visit, I also split an order of fresh spring rolls (I love these things!) with my friend. To be honest, I was underwhelmed. The order was 3 shrimp rolls which were stuffed very well, BUT they were a bit dry and it just did not seem fresh. The rolls were sitting on a bed of wilted lettuce which made it a bit unappealing. The dipping sauce on the side (peanut, oyster and spicy) was definitely a saving grace. The spring rolls tasted okay but could have used a bit more Thai basil and some mint. Staff are polite, attentive and respond quickly without being too intrusive. Decor is simple but warm - very nice place to eat for a first date or a family dinner. Most of the time the dishes are not that spicy, unless you explicitly state that you want them that way.Delivery is pretty reliable too!", 5, 2], "a5DZgwM6WtxIsAEkjgfW9Q": ["Yelp", "Taste of Thai Express", "2/2/2009", "This is my last year in Ithaca as a graduate student at Cornell, and with regret that I report that we found this gem of a place a tad late. As many residents of Ithaca would agree, we are blessed to have a few tasty restaurants in the form of Thai cuisine in Ithaca, and Taste of Thai would obviously go to the top of the list. However, the original flavor that we enjoyed at Taste of Thai began to subside recently-may be the sign of the times?-, I was surprised to find that Taste of Thai Express (hence the Express) offers better tasting food than the former. In the past year, I thought that Express was just a to-go place of Taste of Thai, I did not bother to eat there for some time. Recently, a classmate who can point out very good restaurants treated me with Thai food - chicken sticks, Tom Yan soup, Pad Thai and Shrimp rolls - from the Express, which won me over. Although I believe that the Thai restaurants in Ithaca area offer a rather high quality (even for an Asian like me) of food and services - I visited couple of Thai restaurants in San Francisco during my undergraduate days and can compare my experience from there - , I must say that the Express is the best out of them all. As they say in the website, the material of the food are of high quality (mostly organic food grown in Ithaca), and seem to use less MSG, an artificial ingredient that many Asian restaurants are fond of using. Most of all, as my former PR manager wife who fondly remembers the great food from Singapore during her business trips there, would agree that the taste and the quality of the food from the Express is very much like the ones that she had in Singapore. Although we would order from Express for home delivery, you can certainly visit the place for an on-site dining experience, which we have yet to do so. However, before we get to move on out of the city in summer, we will very likely visit the place in person as well as continuing to order tasty Thai food from the Express. All in all, very good restaurant to satisfy your Asian food cravings.", 5, 1], "I9yfpOBCVqlb1LVS5Hej3Q": ["Yelp", "Taste of Thai Express", "12/1/2008", "I ordered the Pad See Ew, Yellow Curry and Spicy Chicken wings.
